results.description:
WHY ME?  Understanding Karma                                                                                                          a meditation class series 

TUESDAYS | OCT 13th - NOV 17th


7:00 - 8:30pm

with Kadampa Buddhist Teacher, Kyle Davis

Do you ever wonder why certain things, good or bad, happen to you? How can an understanding of Karma change things for the better?

Karma means ‘action’. Every action we perform leaves an imprint on our very subtle mind and each imprint eventually gives rise to its own effect. Our mind is like a field and performing actions is like sowing seeds in that field. In this series, we will explore Buddha’s teachings on Karma. We will learn how to apply its wisdom into our daily lives in beautiful meditations, so that we can learn to accept our present circumstances and joyfully cultivate our future happiness.

Each class includes a short talk and two guided meditations. Everyone welcome - no experience necessary.  

Drop in anytime! No need to pre-registration. 

Cost | $10 per class / $5 students & seniors.  Members FREE! 

Location | 179 Green Street – Boston, Jamaica Plain, MA 02130  

meditationINboston.org

For more info please call[masked] or email [masked]

results.description:
Ongoing class in Medieval and Renaissance Longsword in the tradition of Johannes Lichtenauer.

The Longsword is the iconic fantasy Knight's sword - a two-handed, straight blade with a cross guard. The weapon may seem to be simple at first but is in reality a weapon of finesse and skill.

The class covers all the basics of footwork, attacks and defenses. Drills are developed from simple to complex; from rigidly choreographed to open-ended. Timing, distance and judgement are developed. All classes begin with a Strength & Conditioning program designed to physically prepare one for fighting with the sword. Elements develop agility, core stability and power.

results.description:
This meeting is FREE for ENET Members.  Want to become a member?  Join NOW!


Join us at the PRE-MEETING DINNER at 5:15 PM (sharp) at Bertucci’s Restaurant, 475 Winter Street in Waltham. This is a self-pay dinner where your networking get's started!

Want to get experience pitching in front of a large, friendly audience? Sign-up for ENET's eMinute program

Event Description:

So you and your co-founding team want to start a company? Starting a company without carefully considering some important co-founder questions and issues can significantly undermine your company’s chances of success. What questions should you consider when dividing the initial equity? What do you need to do to ensure the company’s ownership of IP? How do you protect your company and your investors if a co-founder stops working or leaves the company?

To answer these questions, our panel will discuss start-up formalization using founder agreements. These agreements define each team member’s roles and responsibilities as they will appear in legal filings. Equity ownership and vesting will be addressed as will the impact of unequal founder initial investment. Another essential aspect of technology start-ups is intellectual property (IP) ownership. Will some of the founders bring IP with them to the new venture? If so, IP ownership and licensing issues must be settled.

These are just a few of the issues our panel of experienced experts will address on November 3rd. You will also have the opportunity to ask your own questions and to network with others who, like yourself, will be start-up founders.

Panel:

Mimi Evans is a financial professional with the Bullfinch Group, the founder and CEO of Fast Turtle Ventures, and the co-founder and CEO of SalesQuest, a marketing intelligence platform that was acquired by OneSource (now Avention) in 2014. Prior to becoming an entrepreneur Mimi served in sales leadership roles for several large technology companies, including IBM, Netscape, and Lotus. In addition to advising clients, entrepreneurs, start-ups, and small businesses Mimi serves as a Judge and Mentor for Mass Challenge 2015.


Chris Stepanian is a co-founder of Windgap Medical, Inc. ( www.windgapmedical.com ) and has served as President, CEO, and board-member since the Company’s founding. Windgap has developed and is commercializing its patent-pending wet/dry autoinjector platform and proprietary drug formulation to address major deficiencies in the epinephrine autoinjector market, a $1.3 billion dollar opportunity. He has also helped to raise $6.5 million in equity funding from angel, venture, and strategic sources. Windgap’s series A round of investment, just closed, is one of the largest angel/venture co-investment deals in the US this year. He is a long-time entrepreneur with more than 25 years of experience in operations, finance, strategy, and technology. He has experience in aerospace, automotive, contract-research, industrial materials, and healthcare industries. Previously he was a founding team member of Aspen Aerogels ( www.aerogel.com ) in Northborough, MA where he contributed to research, operations, and finance. He is a long-time organizer of the Head of the Charles Regatta® and a former board member of Community Rowing, Inc. He has engineering degrees from Rensselaer and Texas A&M along with an MBA from MIT’s Sloan Fellows program.


Jack M. Swig, Attorney at Law and Counsel at Finance

Mr. Swig’s background and experience span that of senior legal function, private merchant banking, corporate finance and venture capital in diverse roles including lending, bridge financing, and as a venture capital fund manager and in-house counsel in the medical diagnostics, devices and therapeutics sectors. He is well versed in the areas of business and strategic development and corporate alliance. He has, during several periods in his career, been deeply involved in crisis management and developed acumen in turnarounds, workouts and asset recovery with varying stages of private and public enterprises. Prior to undertaking his specialty law and finance practice, he served for more than 12 years as Vice President of Corporate Development and General Counsel for Microfluidics International Corporation (formerly public – MFLU; acquired in 2012 by IDEX Corporation (NYSE: IEX), and its subsidiary, Microfluidics Corporation). Mr. Swig also served as the company’s Investor Relations Manager for almost 15 years, often working with market makers and analysts. Since 2011, Mr. Swig has served, part-time, as In-house Counsel, strategic planner, a capital and funding resource development and coordinator for a Biotech/Medical Device and Cleantech non-profit incubator (that he helped to create and develop). He Interacts with and advises the CEO, COO and Chairman with regard to a wide range of day to day, special project and strategic planning activities. His responsibilities include all legal agreements, technical and business evaluation, due diligence investigation of applicants, needs assessment for applicant companies, assisting portfolio companies with identifying financing prospects and presentations and collaborations.

Since mid-2008 Mr. Swig has been a sole practitioner in his legal and finance consulting practice working extensively with early stage companies on corporate development, financing, strategic partnerships and alliances, and a wide range of matters with clients from pharmaceutical R&D, Life Science Research Tools, Medical Devices, Healthcare, and Cleantech/Energy Savings sectors. His legal work generally revolves around corporate and securities matters, confidentiality, material transfer and related agreements, Intellectual Property strategy and licensing.

Moderator:

Greg Dawe, https://www.linkedin.com/in/gregdawe

Greg Dawe is ENET's Vice Chair of Operations and has been working in the software industry for over 30 years, first as an engineer, and later, in management. For over 10 years, he held senior management positions in the computer network security industry including experience with RSA Security, Inc. Greg specializes in establishing and growing new organizations directly linked to improving company results.

results.description:
BeVisible Latina is the first social networking, and career-building site powered by Latina Millennials. On Tuesday, Nov. 3rd we will be hosting a twitter chat with Latina creatives. #BeCreativa

Although Twitter chats are virtual events, the Boston-based Visibles will be meeting to tweet together over wine and coffee at Jaho Coffee & Wine Bar in Chinatown. (It's easily accessible by all train lines!)

If you've never participated in a Twitter chat before and need some pointers/tech support, come and join us.

The meeting will be very informal, and will be a great opportunity to get connected with our growing community of Latina young professionals and students. 

All you need to bring is your laptop! We will be getting set up at 7:30pm, and the chat begins right at 8pm, so plan to get there at least 15 min beforehand. 

More info on the event:

Tweet it up with the Creativas of #BeVisibleLatina Tuesday, November 3 at 8pm EST.

We'll be sharing personal experiences managing creativity and profit, collaborating in a sharing economy, and our thoughts on future innovation!

Join our #BeCreativa panel of professional creative as they share their stories of pursuing a creative business career.

Denise Cox
Denise is a sought after youth speaker on identity, an entrepreneur, and an experienced Internet marketer. She has built and managed large direct marketing sales teams, and led the sponsorship departments for House of Blues and high visibility Denver-based sporting events. She has been passionate about sharing Enye (ñ) Stories and bringing the concept of Enye (ñ) into mainstream American consciousness since she first realized she was an Enye (ñ) in her mid-twenties.

Fatima Alvarez
Fatima is a proud Latina fashion designer pursuing her dream to empower women by dressing them, and by showing a younger generation that any dream can be achieved; even that of being a Latina designer in America. She is passionate about life and about making the world a better and sweeter place.

Isabel Ann Castro
Isabel is the social media strategist for Desmadre. She grew up in San Antonio, Texas among what she calls “the nopales and hoodrats”. She has always had a creative imagination, a positive outlook, and a “let’s do cool shit” attitude. She holds a degree from Texas State in Communication Design and utilizes her voice as an ambicultural millennial on social media.

Natalie Scenters-Zapico
Natalie is from the sister cities of El Paso, Texas, U.S.A. and Ciudad Juárez, Chihuahua, México. She is the author of The Verging Cities, which is part of the Mountain West Poetry Series (CLP June 2015). A CantoMundo fellow, her poems have appeared in American Poets, The Believer, Prairie Schooner, West Branch, Best American Poetry 2015, and more. She teaches English and creative writing, and coordinates the student-led literary magazine Tepeyac at Juan Diego Catholic High School. Natalie lives in Salt Lake City with her husband, border rhetorics scholars José Ángel Maldonado.

Tariana V. Little
Tariana is co-founder of EmVision Productions, a story-driven media production company that creates digital marketing content. A researcher by training, Tariana enjoys using data and multimedia communications for real world impact. In addition to her writing, teaching, and community projects, Tariana is a visual artist (TVLENSES) focused on capturing human stories. Driven by science, storytelling, and social justice, Tariana’s work embodies what she calls “intentional creativity for social change.”

We, Ceremony
We, Ceremony is a visual platform dedicated to women of color (woc) that seeks to recognize the different faces of style, and through these lenses, increase our cultural capacity. Realizing how much they have in common—from their frustration towards whiteness to the normalcy of gender inequality—Iliana and Mu began to regard their cultural individuality as a celebration of diverse experiences. We, Ceremony is a response to the lack of representation of woc and to the negative portrayal of woc in everyday life. Iliana and Mu hope to create a space where woc can come together and find comfort in their shared experiences.


http://www.bevisible.soy/posts/60430

To join our online platform: www.bevisible.soy/register
results.name: #BeCreativa Twitter Chat + In-person Coffee & Wine Meetup

results.description:
https://scontent.fphl1-1.fna.fbcdn.net/hphotos-xat1/v/t1.0-9/11065856_1207361139280039_2399819844549418486_n.jpg?oh=df247796f26b38d33330fd37fca81e0c&oe=56BD4E85

Ben Hunter & Joe Seamons
http://www.benjoemusic.com/
The history of American roots music in the early 20th century could never fit into an encyclopedia. it’s too ramshackle, too rambunctious, too radical. Fiddlers, guitarists, banjo players, and all kinds of folks rambled those early roads, learning from each other, inspiring each other, and pushing the music in new directions. Music constantly switched back and forth across the racial divide, beholden only to the beat and the dance. It’s this fevered period of musical exchange that inspires Northwest roots music duo Ben Hunter & Joe Seamons. The songs on their new album, Take Yo Time, tap into everything from the hokum jug bands of Gus Cannon and the Memphis Sheiks, to country blues masters Reverend Gary Davis, Robert Johnson, and Blind Willie McTell. They also touch on ancient English ballads like House Carpenter, Appalachian murder ballads like the classic Tom Dooley, and the early jazz compositions of Shelton Brooks and Duke Ellington. All of these traditions are tied together in the swirling musical whirlpool of pre-war American music. With a well-rosined fiddle and an old banjo, Ben Hunter & Joe Seamons are tracing these backroads, bringing the songs back to life.

Ben and Joe have been playing together for almost 5 years, the last 3 of which sent them to the Port Townsend Acoustic Blues Festival, learning at the feet of the elders of the acoustic blues tradition. They found an affinity in the many branches that tied into the blues and created this duo as a way to explore these branches. Their musical kinship and sense of joy in interpreting this music is evident and was the basis of an invitation Dom Flemons (formerly of the Carolina Chocolate Drops) to form his band when he went solo. Ben and Joe joined Dom on his recent album, Prospect Hill, and toured the US with him, furthering their knowledge of Anglo and African American music traditions. Rather than thinking of their music as blues, it’s best to situate Ben and Joe (and Dom) as American songsters. A songster traditionally refers to an African-American artist whose repertoire is much broader than the old blues, and spans many of the genres that Ben and Joe Inhabit. Big Bill Broonzy and Mississippi John Hurt are classic examples of songsters. Whatever you want to call it, Ben Hunter & Joe Seamons make American music. They make music that hews to the rough-and-tumble collisions of musical inspirations from the early 20th century; music that paved the way for everything we enjoy today.

Elijah Wald & Sandrine Sheon
Elijah Wald is a guitarist and singer whose repertoire ranges from old blues and folk songs to ragtime, swing, and classic Swahili pop. After an apprenticeship studying guitar and drinking till dawn with Dave Van Ronk, he has played all over the US, as well as Europe, India, and the Congo. He worked as an accompanist to Eric Von Schmidt, played for five years with the legendary African-American fiddler and mandolinist Howard Armstrong, studied with the Congolese masters Jean-Bosco Mwenda and Edward Masengo, and has recorded an instructional DVD on the music of the Bahamian virtuoso Joseph Spence. He has also written a dozen books on blues, folk, pop, and Mexican music, and there's plenty more info about all of this at http://www.elijahwald.com. In recent years he has been performing with Sandrine Sheon on clarinet, combining their repertoires and underlining the close links between blues, country, ragtime, folk, and jazz.

Admission by donation, $10 students/seniors, $15-20 all others suggested.
As this is a small space, reservations via Eventbrite are strongly recommended -
http://www.eventbrite.com/e/ben-hunter-joe-seamons-w-elijah-wald-sandrine-sheon-tickets-19032796607

Free parking: 44 spaces in the back lot, or on the street (mind the signs).
MBTA: Arts at the Armory is approximately a 15 minute walk from Davis Square which is on the MBTA Red Line. You can also find us by using either the MBTA RT 88 and RT 90 bus that can be caught either at Lechmere (Green Line) or Davis Square (Red Line). Get off at the Highland Avenue and Lowell Street stop. You can also get there from Sullivan Square (Orange Line) by using the MBTA RT 90 bus. Get off at the Highland Avenue and Benton Road stop.
Bicycle: The Armory is four blocks (down Lowell Street) from the Somerville Community Path.
More info: http://artsatthearmory.org/about/getting-here/

results.description:
Over the course of this meetup group, we have had only one woman (myself) who attended more than 1 meetup. 3 other women have attended one meetup each but opted not to return. I have met with one of these, who voiced her concern that (at least at the one meetup she attended) some of the men present failed to value input to the discussion from the 3 women present as much as input from the 3 men. She agreed to come to this meetup (Nov. 3) so we can all look at this issue together. I sincerely hope that reading this will encourage some of the other women who have signed up but never actually attended a discussion, to attend this one! We will also continue to discuss our primary goal: how to achieve a truly egalitarian world society. I also affirm that clearly, the word "egalitarian" implies no hierarchy among people of any skin color, or any gender identity, including not only straight men and women, but also gays, Lesbians and people who identify as Trans or Queer.


Comments are welcome!
results.name: Discuss: Is gender inequality a potential obstacle to egalitarianism?

results.description:
Meditation practice gives us a chance to step away from the busy-ness of our day-to-day lives. It provides space for us to be free from reaction, from expectation, from doing, and step into the gentle space of being.

This weekly practice consists of 25-30 minutes of guided Vipassana meditation followed by a brief discussion. Vipassana meditation encourages us to experience each moment exactly how it is, fostering presence and awareness.

In this practice we allow thoughts, emotions, and all other stimuli to surface. We become a witness of these, cultivating a space of non-attachment and revealing a deeper connection with one's inner self.

Newcomers to meditation and long-time practitioners are welcome to attend. This is a FREE practice. There is a suggested donation, but that is not required to attend.

The space is divided into nine aesthetically distinct rooms featuring exquisite detail in decor and design; the Great wall Gallery, Bar and Lounge, Salon, Imperial Dining Room, Persimmon Room, three private dining rooms served by a private bar and an Asian awe-inspiring open kitchen at the heart. results.description:
In this class you will be introduced to medical Qi Gong which also sometimes called “Chinese Yoga” and is an “energy workout” developed by Chinese doctors and professors at the University of Physical Education and Sports Medicine in China.

It is great for body and mind healing, anxiety and stress relief, developing good posture and balance, disease prevention and recovery from injury and/or surgery.

Through gentle whole body stretching and Qi breathing you will feel the energy flow smoothly through your body.

It is proven to relieve many ailments: back pain, neck and shoulder problems, cardiac ailments and circulation problems, low energy, low immune function, GI problems, muscle stiffness, arthritic complaints and many others.

It involves whole body movements, gentle stretching, proper breathing, as well as self-massage to promote smooth energy (Qi) flow in the body.

1.30 hour class: basics of QiGong, warm-up, Therapeutic Qi-Gong form, self-massage and relaxation.

Recommended level: Beginner. This is an excellent preventative and recuperative exercise for all ages, and especially recommended for those who are 35+.

Where: 


Tai Chi Acupuncture & Wellness Center, LLC

7 Bow St Ste 1, North Reading, MA

Price:  FREE (regular price for the Intro class - $20)

results.description:
There have been a lot of meetups lately with more on the way. However, most (all?) are in the evening or on weekends. I'd like to start a MeetUp that would meet twice a month at the Robbins Library in Arlington, where Mass Ave crosses Route 60. The Meetup would take place on a weekday afternoon from 1 to 3 or 2 to 4.

I'd pattern it after Strummerville. There would be a set book of songs and would be open to all levels. I'm not sure about whether it would be a good idea to use the first half hour or tack an extra half hour onto the front to focus on beginners.

I'll likely give it a try regardless, putting up posters at the library and using the Town's bulletin board to make it known, but I'm eager to learn whether there is any interest in the UUoB.

results.description:
Do you VEGETABLE-TARIANS want all the OTHER people (even if they have not committed to be vegetarians) to eat fresh produce?  Then help us - each Wednesday late afternoon - bag vegetables (and some fruit) for the neighbors in Mission Hill.  Usually there are also freshly-baked loaves of bread, also (baked that morning - Jessica's Bakery).

It's an assembly line, then take home a bag (or two) of produce for yourself. 


Bring your business cards, smartphone, or notepad, and prepare to exchange contact info with other volunteers you like.  Volunteers come from several sources (not merely this meetup or others:Craigslist, Pharmacy School, School of Public Health, etc.) 

~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
VOLUNTEERING for $2/bag of produce in Mission Hill
Tobin Community Center, 1481 Tremont Street
Mission Hill, Roxbury
(between Brigham Circle and Roxbury Crossing T stops)
Boston, MA 02120 - <2 blocks from Orange Line T Each Wednesday, from 4:00 - 6:00 pm (indoors in bad weather)

We will be VOLUNTEERING for the weekly Wednesday late afternoon $2/bag of produce in Mission Hill.

When you volunteer,
YOU will ALSO TAKE HOME one or two of those "$2 bags"!
We've had 55 volunteers, and we've had 7.  Workloads vary!

Fair Foods provides a 20-22 bag of produce for the Mission Hill neighbors so they can eat like me - on produce. The neighbors only need to pay' $2 for the bag.

Volunteers unload the truck, set up 3 banquet tables, set up the food in order of desntiy (potatoes on bottom - tomatoes and bananas and berries and kale on top), then fill each bag (and 'stack' them upright by one another - for the 'paying neighbors' to pick up (for $2).


We arrive around 4 pm (maybe as late as 4:30 pm) and work until 6 pm (can leave as early as 5:30 pm if we've finished).

In the FRONT of the Tobin Community Center, 1481 Tremont Street (between the Brigham Circle T stop - GREEN E-Line - and the Roxbury Crossing Orange Line T stop), behind the wrought iron fence.

Wear comfortable clothing that allows you to move flexibly and to actually work, lifting heavy bags of food. 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 
Tobin Community Center 
1481 Tremont Street, Boston, MA

THERE IS NO PARKING - IT'S BEST FOR THOSE WHO LIVE IN BOSTON AND TRAVEL IN ON THE MBTA

THERE IS NO PARKING IN THE NEIGHBORHOOD

Every Wednesday, from 4:00 - 6:00 pm

Boston, MA 02120 - <2 blocks from Orange Line T Each Wednesday, from 4:00 - 6:00 pm (indoors in bad weather)


We will be VOLUNTEERING for the weekly Wednesday late afternoon $2/bag of produce in Mission Hill.

When you volunteer,
YOU will ALSO TAKE HOME one or two of those "$2 bags"! 
We've had 55 volunteers, and we've had 7.  Workloads vary!

Fair Foods provides a 20-22 bag of produce for the Mission Hill neighbors so they can eat like me - on produce. The neighbors only need to pay' $2 for the bag.

Volunteers unload the truck, set up 3 banquet tables, set up the food in order of desntiy (heavy food, such as potatoes or onions, on the bottom - lighter, more perishable foods, such as tomatoes and bananas and berries and kale on top), then fill each bag (and 'stack' them upright by one another - for the 'paying neighbors' to pick up (for $2).

Some arrive as early as 3:30 pm (you don't NEED to do that, but you're welcome to do so; OUR meetup's attendees - it's posted on 6 meetups - are often there early, and you can chat).

We (MOST of us) arrive around 4 pm (maybe as late as 4:30 pm) and work until 6 pm (can leave as early as 5:30 pm if we've finished).

In the FRONT of the Tobin Community Center, 1481 Tremont Street (between the Brigham Circle T stop - GREEN E-Line - and the Roxbury Crossing Orange Line T stop), behind the wrought iron fence.

Wear comfortable clothing that allows you to move flexibly and to actually work, lifting heavy bags of food.

Admission to the MFA (The Boston Museum of Fine Arts) is free after 4pm on Wednesdays!!

We get together in the Longwood Medical Area on Tuesday evenings for bilingual chat, but just a few blocks away is one of the world's finest art museums (and it also has a section on Sinology or China studies).

November 06, 2015


Rated:

R


Synopsis:

Starring Michael Keaton, Mark Ruffalo, Rachel McAdams, Liev Schreiber, Brian d’Arcy James and Stanley Tucci, SPOTLIGHT tells the riveting true story of the Pulitzer Prize-winning Boston Globe investigation that would rock the city and cause a crisis in one of the world’s oldest and most trusted institutions. When the newspaper’s tenacious “Spotlight” team of reporters delve into allegations of abuse in the Catholic Church, their year-long investigation uncovers a decades-long cover-up at the highest levels of Boston's religious, legal, and government establishment, touching off a wave of revelations around the world. Directed by Academy Award-nominee Tom McCarthy, SPOTLIGHT is a tense investigative thriller, tracing the steps to one of the biggest crime stories in modern times.

results.description:
Come enthrall in Fall fun with Coalition Boston! We will have some great drinks (think pumpkin beers and cider), homemade snacks and bites, networking, music and SCORE mentoring sessions! This event will be especially unique since we will incorporate a potluck! We did this last year and it was a huge success so we want to make this a special Coalition tradition. Bringing foods or goods are by no means a requirement but if you must bring something, we will happily accept! :)

While networking, meet the successful businesses and entrepreneurs that form Coalition's entrepreneurial community, including investors, marketers, developers, and professional service providers. To register for this event all guest must RSVP on our Eventbrite page as well https://www.eventbrite.com/e/coalitions-fall-potluck-tickets-18962837357. 

SCORE will be extending their FREE business mentoring services to the Coalition community. There are only a few slots for 1-on-1 sessions with our SCORE mentor and former management consultant Laura Colcord. For her bio, and to book an appt, click this link, it's first come first served! https://www.timetrade.com/book/33J81

Also a special thank you to our sponsor TriNet - read below about how they contribute to our entrepreneurial community!

About Coalition: Coalition is a top coworking space in Downtown Crossing (hyper-centrally located atop the red, orange, and green lines!). All of our members are revenue-generating and over half are veteran entrepreneurs with multiple businesses.  Our spaces and events are built to make it easier for entrepreneurs to bounce ideas off each other.  Community is very important to us, as we work to connect our members to the startup ecosystem, investors, and others who can help you grow. Join the Coalition! 

About TriNet: TriNet is a cloud-based professional employer organization for small and medium-sized businesses. TriNet administers payroll and health benefits and advises clients on employment law compliance and risk reduction.

About SCORE:A nonprofit dedicated to helping small businesses get off the ground, grow and achieve their goals through education and mentorship. Whether you are a start up or existing business, SCORE mentors will discuss your business or idea and determine the mentoring support that would be most beneficial.
results.name: Coalition's Fall Potluck!

http://mfas3.s3.amazonaws.com/styles/banner_grid-9_retina/s3/SC310172_4x3_2.jpg?itok=yjstDRdV

Enjoy an evening of dance, tours, and art making at the MFA to celebrate Diwali—the Festival of Lights enjoyed around the world by many cultures and religions. Explore three highlights from our collection of South Asian art; watch a festive performance by Chhandika, a Kathak dance group whose swift footwork tells traditional Indian stories; and make art with Sunanda Sahay as she demonstrates the fine art of Madhubani, or Mithila, painting.

All events are free as the MFA has free admission on Wednesdays after 4pm.


Special Events

Artist Demonstration and Art Making: Madhubani Painting | 6–8:30 pm, Education Center in Druker Family Pavilion, Room 159 
Dance Performance: Kathak Dance of Northern India | 6:30–7 pm and 7:30–8 pm, Shapiro Family Courtyard
Pop-Up Performance: Saraswathi Jones | 8:30–8:45 pm, Gallery 176 
Drawing in the Galleries | 6–9 pm, Gallery 177 

Tours and Talks

Spotlight Talks: Sitar | 6, 6:30, and 7:15 pm, Musical Instruments Gallery, 103 
Gallery Tours: South Asian Highlights | 6:15, 7, and 7:45 pm, Meet at the Sharf Visitor Center 
Lecture: Diwali around the World | 7–7:30 pm, Riley Seminar Room, 156
results.name: Diwali Celebration @ MFA

Recent lesson learned: Never pull a ticket for NY to LA when another player only has 8 trains left. Keep those eyes open.

1.  Having difficulty modernizing your company’s legacy User Interface?

2.  Want to learn about how to leverage some of the newest Javascript frameworks?

3.  Want to share about particular problems or solutions/ breakthroughs you've had in dealing with your enterprise UI?

4.  Interested in networking with other UI developers with similar experiences? 

If you have answered yes to any of these questions, this meetup is for you.  Our inaugural meeting will be an open forum for everyone, including developers, designers and product managers to discuss the biggest problems they face, the coolest tips/tricks they have implemented, and how they have leveraged cutting edge technologies such as the advanced Javascript frameworks (React.js, Node.js, Backbone.js, etc.)

Format:

6pm-6:30pm – Networking (Food and Beer provided)

6:30pm-6:45pm – Introduction about the Meetup and the group’s goals

6:45-8:00pm – Sharing/ Discussion/Brainstorming

Please bring some form of identification (such as driver's license).

results.description:
Please RSVP for this game so we know we have enough people.

6:30-6:45 pm - Warm up & practice, we'll work on some throws, passes & catches.

6:45 pm - Game starts.

General guidelines: Dress accordingly. Bring a white & dark shirt so we can easily divide into 2 teams. Have plenty of water. Sunscreen on a sunny day. Stretch & warm up. We'll provide discs and cones.

Weather: Rain in New England is unpredictable. We will send out a final notice one hour before start time if cancellation is necessary.

RSVP: Very helpful as this is how we contact you in case of game changes & cancellations.

About: Playing Ultimate is all about good sportsmanship, respect, and gracefulness on the field.  Fun & having a good time is a must above anything else. It's an easy game to pick up & we keep the rules minimal. No zones, no stall count, no scores, and players self-officiate on the field.  Open to all levels of players.  Beginners welcome.

Warning: Excessive fun & comradery developed from playing Ultimate may become addicting.

results.description:
I've copied the following information from the Facebook event page.

Register HERE: https://www.eventbrite.com/e/freeze-frame-black-boston-2015-a-case-for-inclusion-tickets-19302593577

We wanted to update you on what is happening with Freeze Frame: Black Boston 2015, A Case For Inclusion. It's clear we have hit a nerve both within and outside of our community. There is still much more work to do. The support for this effort is growing daily and coming from some interesting and unexpected places.

We have held several meetings to obtain feedback...and will continue to collaborate to refine the presentation and Next Steps.

Our goal is to secure our fair share of the economic pie for both Black businesses and residents. Our next public presentation of Freeze Frame will be done... at a community meeting on Wednesday, November 4th, 2015, 6:00-9:00 PM, Prince Hall Grand Lodge, 24 Washington St, Grove Hall. Save-the-date and invite everyone! We want to fill the house. Just another way to communicate that we're serious!

For those of you who could not attend on September 30, you should know that we discussed two very exciting initiatives that are included in the enclosed Next Steps. We're creating a Massachusetts Black Chamber of Commerce ("MBCOC"). Equally exciting, we're creating a Black Political Action Committee ("BlackPAC") to focus financial support and create accountability to elected officials who support our goal of real economic inclusion for Black businesses and Black residents of our community and Black communities across the state. Just this past weekend, we secured our first PAC commitment from a Black business in Worcester. Same issue, different zip code! We set a goal of raising $100,000 in founding member commitments by the end of this month through $5,000 commitments and $1,500 commitments for the under 45 entrepreneurs. We are close to achieving our goal!

We encourage you to consider being a founding member by making your BlackPAC commitment by October 25th. We'll be announcing the final tally at the November 4th meeting. Remember, as a result of the Citizens United vs. FEC, corporations can make PAC donations.

We will continue to keep you updated on the progress. We respect your time and attention because we know that you are busy. So when we call on you, know that it is because your presence is important. WE need you on November 4th.
results.name: Freeze Frame: Black Boston 2015, A Case For Inclusion

results.description:
The partners of the Café des Entrepreneurs are glad to welcome Mr. Eric Stevenson, Director for the Americas of Aldebaran Robotics. Mr. Stevenson will be interviewed by François Ducroux, former head of the French-American Chamber of Commerce of New-England (FACCNE). 
​Presentation in English. 


<a></a>
Eric Stevenson is Director for the Americas for Aldebaran Robotics. leading sales and operations for the US and Latin American region. Prior to Aldebaran, Eric worked for Hewlett-Packard EMEA in a variety of sales and marketing leadership roles across the company’s portfolio of hardware, software and services. He also has previous experience with Bain & Co. and Procter & Gamble. Eric earned an MBA from IMD in Lausanne, Switzerland.

Aldebaran Robotics:
Established in 2005, with offices in France, China, Japan and the United States, Aldebaran designs, produces and sells interactive and emotional humanoid robots. Aldebaran currently has over 450 employees involved in the development and production of robots. Aldebaran believes in a future where interactive, communicating robots will accompany humans in their jobs, their homes and with their hobbies, their family life. Today Aldebaran has three robots: NAO, Pepper and Romeo.

​The interview will be followed by an exclusive panel discussion with the French "Innovators under 35" MIT Tech Review Award recipients [masked]). Come listen to their backgrounds, experiences and success stories!

For more details on the[masked] winners: http://www.technologyreview.com/lists/innovators-under-35/2014/http://www.technologyreview.com/lists/innovators-under-35/2014/ http://www.tr35france.com/laureats/

For more info on EMTECH 2-4 Nov. 2015: http://www.technologyreview.com/emtech/15/
​ 

- See more at: http://www.lcdeboston.com/#sthash.V4dumVNO.dpuf

results.description:
Want to learn Public Speaking but not sure where to start?

Are you afraid of speaking in front of groups?

Use filler words like 'um', 'and', 'like', 'you know'?

Have no idea how to structure an interesting speech? 

Then this is the place for you.

EXPERIENTIAL LEARNING

Our hands on class will give you a safe, supportive and fun atmosphere to practice public speaking with other beginners  who are also your supportive audience.


PERSONALIZED COACHING

When you sign up I'll ask you 1-2 specific goals you want to learn in class and I'll teach it to you!  

It's a customized syllabus designed by you.  

Not sure where to start? No worries, I'll teach you the beginning steps.

CREATE CONFIDENCE

Fear of speaking in front of a group?  

Not to worry...you'll learn the coping mechanisms the professionals use and the fear will turn to excitement!


VIDEO FEEDBACK

Optional video taping of your speech is available so you can see yourself and make your own evaluation.  

We upload your practice speeches to Dropbox and only the class students can see it later.  

We can also video tape with just your smartphone for super privacy.  

It's a powerful tool to evaluate yourself.


OTHER BENEFITS

Learn how to give a speech without notes and never forget what to say!


How about getting rid of those pesky 'ums', 'likes', 'you knows' and other filler words?  That's part of the class.


Have a specific project or presentation?  Practice it in this class.  


Let the President of Toastmasters Boston Copley share with you the basics of solid speech making.


Our small classes are designed to give you the individual attention, feedback and suggestions to help you thrive!

MONEY BACK GUARANTEE

If you feel it's not worth your money you get a 100% refund.  No questions asked.

SAVE $40

BRING A FRIEND AND YOU BOTH ATTEND THE 'PRACTICE + PERSONALIZED COACHING' CLASS ON THE SAME EVENING FOR FREE. A $40 VALUE.

See you there!

results.description:
Hello ASL Enthusiasts!

A number of folks living NORTH of Boston have asked about an ASL SOCIAL. Let's make this happen!

On WEDNESDAYS, starting October 29 - 6pm to 8pm - I / we will be at the NORTH SHORE MALL Food Court.

While technology has improved the way people communicate, "Deaf Social Clubs" are slowly disappearing. This is a way to start bringing REAL social interaction back!

Please join us for a casual, relaxed, no-pressure two-hour Social, where we can chat, tell stories, get to know each other, and meet new people (or old friends!). Friends, Fun and Food!

A warm welcome is extended to all Deaf & non-Deaf people: folks in the Deaf Community, CODA's, Interpreters, ASL students, parents of deaf children AND their children, ASL professors/teachers, Relay Operators, Deaf services workers- EVERYONE!

This will be a "SOME ASL KNOWLEDGE and ABOVE" Social, because not all of us are ASL-fluent! "Voices- Off" -- we'll all laugh & learn WITH and FROM each other!

WHAT: ASL SOCIAL CLUB
WHERE: North Shore Mall Food Court, PEABODY,MA
DAY/TIME: Wednesdays, 6pm - 8pm
WHY: To meet like-minded people, socialize using ASL, tell stories, and have good time!
WHO: Anyone who wants to chat using American Sign Language!
HOW TO FIND US:  We'll be sitting on the couches closest to the "walkway" side of the Food Court, not hidden inside the food court, so easier to locate us!

If you have any question, please contact Connie or Paul I., through the EMAIL LINK via BOSTON ASL profile page.

PLEASE, if you would be good enough, RSVP either "YES" or "NO" so I know who to look for!

CHEERS!

Connie Cassidy / Paul I.

PEACE...

results.description:
Topic: PowerShell & Source Code Management  (SCM)

Presenter: Gene Laisne & Fotios Magoufis

Gene is going to go over some more helpful tips for using PowerShell in everyday work. If there is any subject you'd like him to cover, leave notes in the Meetup page. Gene will answer your questions and help you better understand how you can use PowerShell to automate just about anything.

Fotios Magoufis is going to go over Source Code Management systems like GitHub and others. He'll show you how to better utilize these systems to help maintain the code you've worked so hard to put together.

Directions:  Please come to the main entrance of 1 Cambridge Center, located at the corner of Broadway and Main streets.  Proceed to the second floor and check in with reception.  You will be directed to the elevators towards the back of the space.  Go to the fourth floor.

Parking:  Meters don’t require payments past 8pm.  Meters have a 2 hour limit, so if you can find a meter around 6pm you'll be good for the night.  There are several pay lots including Standard Parking at 1 Broadway Street or the Marriot parking lot.  The MIT lots are NOT free, and while many people park there the school reserves the right to tow and ticket.

See the section at the bottom of the page titled

"Parking at MIT without a Permit".
http://web.mit.edu/facilities/transportation/parking/visitors/public_parking.html

results.description:
Dear Boston Culture Lovers,


The Museum of Fine Arts is hosting a special Divvali: The Festival of Lights event.

...

Enjoy an evening of dance, tours, and art making at the MFA to celebrate Divvali. This Festival of Lights is enjoyed around the world by many cultures and religions—hear a lecture on the topic; tour the galleries exploring works of art related to the Hindu, Jain, and Sikh religions; and watch a festive performance by Chhandika, a group of Kathak dancers who use swift and precise footwork to tell traditional Indian stories.

http://www.mfa.org/programs/special-event/diwali-the-festival-of-lights


...


The plan is to meet at 6pm in lounge/couch area of the Sharf Visitor Center on the first floor. The plan is to gather as a group for 15 minutes and at 6 :15 pm, we will start exploring the Diwali museum events.

Since this event will be a somewhat crowded and roaming , it will be very difficult for latecomers to connect with the group. If you are late, I can not guarantee that you will recognize me or fellow members or we to be able recognize you from the crowds. Once the event starts, I put away my smartphone and concentrate on enjoying the event with fellow group members. Please plan ahead and allow a little extra travel time to this event.

If you need to familiarize yourself to this location, here is a link to the floor plan: http://mfas3.s3.amazonaws.com/Map_June2015_level1.pdf I strongly recommend taking public transportation, the Green E line stops right in front of the museum. Also there are several buses that also stop in front of the museum. Check out these links for more information on getting to the museum: http://www.mfa.org/visit/getting-here, www.mbta.com .

Please only reserve "YES" if you are definitely attending and plan to meet members of the group. If you reserve "YES" and have a change of plans, please update the attendance reservation.

I look forward to enjoying this event with the group.

Joana
results.how_to_find_us: 6 pm at the Sharf Visitor Center couch/lounge area
results.name: Divvali The Festival of Lights at the MFA (Free Event)

results.description:
From the porpoise that provided desperately needed sustenance for travellers to the New World to a recipe for ‘French bisket’ and a witchcraft judge's record of the declaration of a day of Thanksgiving, the New England Historic Genealogical Society is full of treasures. Archivist Judy Lucey will reveal the lives of ordinary people through the records of food, their recipes for medicine (‘against settling of cold against ye head & stomach’) and their account books documenting the cost of food in the market.

Dr Lori Stokes, a member of the Partnership of Historic Bostons and a brilliant and popular communicator, will explore five unusual beliefs about food during the 17th century. Like most Europeans, Puritans were highly suspicious of vegetables; their solution: boil it!

The event is co-sponsored by the Partnership of Historic Bostons as part of the 2015 Charter Day celebrations. An RSVP is recommended at http://www.eventbrite.com/e/stirring-up-the-past-puritan-beliefs-about-food-registration-18114986412?aff=eac2

This event is free and open to the public. If you have additional questions, please call[masked] or email [masked].
results.name: Stirring Up the Past: Puritan Beliefs About Food

results.description:
Come join David and friends for a night of Magic: The Gathering over at Not Your Average Joe's in Medford. This event is part of our "Wednesday Night Magic" series.

It doesn't matter if you are an expert "planeswalker", or don't know anything about Magic: The Gathering -- you can come to play or learn this amazing strategy game.  There are usually between 6-12 people at each event, consisting of all experience levels.  All decks of all types are welcome for this "casual play" event.  Beginners who want to learn are welcome!

This location is easily accessible from Rt. 16, Rt. 28 and Rt. 93, and is walking distance from the T, near the new Station Landing apartment complex. Here is a map of the area.

By Subway: Take the Orange Line to Wellington. Walk over the skybridge and cross through the parking lot. Upon exiting the garage, you'll see a building complex (SL75) across the street. Cross the street and take a right. Follow around this building and you'll find Not Your Average Joe's on the opposite side of the street.

By Car: If you are driving, be aware that Station Landing is at the intersection of Rt. 16 and Rt. 28, and you can enter the Station Landing complex from the north-bound side of Rt. 28, or the east-bound side of Rt. 16. There are a number of stores in the Station Landing complex -- look for the Margarita's, Starbucks or Not Your Average Joe's signs. NYAJ is located right off of Rte. 28. Although there is free parking all around the building, we recommend that MTG Boston members park in the garage underneath the restaurant.
results.name: Wednesday Magic In Medford

results.description:
Get in shape before the season!! The leader (Bob Barnes) of the Wedeln Ski and Snowboard Race Team will hold dryland training every Wednesday night this Fall. The workout is great for anyone who wants to get in shape, you do not have to be a skier or racer. Bob's enthusiasm for skiing and training is contagious, he will get you working hard and getting results. All fitness levels are welcome but come ready to sweat. Bob will lead the group in Plyometric based training methods designed to get the leg muscles ready for the season. This is the same workout that he has used for many years to prepare for the ski season.

There is no charge - we are just a bunch of skiers and riders trying to help each other get in shape. Darlene Stokes and Tom Lane will also lead the group in additional exercises designed to increase flexibility and build a strong core. Last year we had many people from Meetup join us for these workouts. Some even became regular guests up at our ski house in NH. Ski Fitness Training is a great way to get ready for the season and make some friends you can join on the slopes when the weather gets colder. The workouts last 1.5 hours and are always immediately followed by a few drinks and sometimes some food at a variety of Waltham Center Bars/Restaurants. Please wear work-out clothes and athletic shoes with some ankle support.
results.how_to_find_us: We will meet in the center of Waltham common near the flag poles.
results.name: Pre-season ski fitness training

results.description:
Whether you live in Emacs or think it is an icecream store, please join use for this introduction of Emacs and ensuing discussion.  We are pleased to have Aaron Bello of Hosttor as our speaker.

Background information on Emacs:

• https://www.gnu.org/software/emacs/

• http://www.gnu.org/software/emacs/tour/


About Aaron Bello:

Aaron Bello is an engineer, entrepreneur and a computer programmer. He is the founder and CEO of Hosttor Inc., a technology and consulting company based in Boston, Massachusetts. He has work on various projects with universities, governments, corporations and organizations.

Aaron started his IT journey at a local computer workshop in 1998. When he was in university, he developed an interest in programming languages after taking BASIC, COBOL, Fortran, Pascal, C and C++, VB and other classes.

How Aaron Uses Emacs:


Aaron now uses and lives in GNU Emacs daily for note taking, to-do lists, time tracking, chat on IRC, twitter, creating documents with LaTex and org-mode, checking mail, news, RSS feeds, writing article and posting to PBN, playing chess, developing and managing all websites projects with HTML, CSS, PHP, JS, Python, Django, API, SSH, FTP, SCP, Drupal, Wordpress, Joomla, Vagrant, Web-servers and many more.


Thank You Akamai

Akamai has generously agreed to provide space and 'free as in food' for this meeting. Thank you to our sponsor! http://www.akamai.com/

Do you have a family member or friend who wants to get in shape but doesn't know how to start? Help get them walking or jogging.

We have 2 groups:

Our Walking Group will exercise and encourage one another towards walking a 5K. 

Our Jogging Group has a goal of jogging a 5K.

Using CoolRunning.com’s Couch To 5K program we introduce people to jogging and getting fit. The program gradually moves you from walking at your own pace to jogging at your own pace.

• FREE 8-week program to get you from the couch to running a 5K (3.1 miles).

•  Anyone from the community can participate. 


• Led by experienced runners. 


• Mondays through Thursdays 6:30pm-7:15pm; Saturdays 10 am-10:45 am 


• 45 minute time commitment (3 days a week) 


• Goal of jogging and finishing a 5K

• Our Fall session will begin on Monday, September 28.

(Please consult your doctor if you have a health or medical condition that prevents you from exercising.)

Encourage those you love to get “off the couch” and join you in the great sport of running. Come have some fun! Bring a water bottle and join the group at the Dedham High School Track.

Our Couch to 5K will end with the "Dedham Turkey Trot" on Thanksgiving morning.

results.description:
Come join us for a midweek climb!


All levels are welcome! If you are new to climbing, there is a belay class at 7 PM. Here is the link to sign up: www.centralrockgym.com/bookeo.php?s=watertown 

I will happily belay those who have not climbed before up until 7 PM, but then it's really important to know how to belay and to take the belay test that starts at 7 PM. You can rejoin the group after taking the belay test.

For those of you who already know how to belay, no need to take the class, you just need to pass this gym's belay test when you arrive.

The price is as follows:

Membership: $89/month

Adult Day Pass: $22 

Gear (shoes, harness, belay device): $8 ($5 for members)

Belay class: $15 (free for members)

Belay test: Free

We will meet at the cluster of cubbies on the first floor at 6:30 PM, greet each other, make sure everyone has a group or person to climb with then head off to climb. I'm looking into whether there is a place nearby to grab a bite or drink at the end of the night. If you have a place in mind, please let me know.

I'll send a message letting you know what color shirt and pants I am wearing incase you arrive late and want to search for us. I will also swing by the cubbies every 15 minutes until everyone who signed up has arrived. So, if you are not able to make it or are running late, PLEASE COMMUNICATE on this event's chat or by contacting my cell-phone, which I will send out once you are confirmed for the event.

Hope you can make it! I'm looking forward to meeting more climbers in the area.

~Avery~
results.how_to_find_us: Will meet at 6:30 PM at the cubbies by the stairs

results.description:
Are you separated/divorced, considering divorce, or in the divorce process?

You are invited to the OPEN HOUSE DIVORCE EXPO. 

Please join us for an evening hosted by divorce professionals, including legal, real estate, parenting, finances, nutrition, career coaching, parenting coaching, relationship coaching, and more. This evening is intended to provide face-to-face interactions in an informal environment with experts in various fields at no cost. As a group of experienced professionals, we understand the complexities of divorce and separation and the need for a holistic approach towards the process to create fewer bumps along the way. Bring your curiosity, questions, or concerns! Whether you are thinking about separation or divorce, getting divorced, or are already divorced, we know these are important resources that can aid in educating and empowering you through the process.

The event starts at 6:30 p.m., but feel welcome to come anytime between 6:30 and 8:30 p.m. You will be able to go in and out at your convenience. 

Complimentary light bites, wine and other refreshments will be provided for your enjoyment throughout the event.

results.description:
ABOUT THE CLASS

Just as buildings have architecture, user experience does, too. Only instead of steel and concrete, experience scaffolding is partially comprised of the user journey or how a user gets from a starting point to what she desires in the most delightful way possible.

We’ll find out what a user journey is, see user journeys for professional work, and work together to make our own.

TAKEAWAYS

• Learn what experience scaffolding (IA) and user journeys are

• Understand how user journeys work

• Best practices in user journeys

• Know how to create delightful user journeys

CLASS SCHEDULE

The class will take place on Wednesday November 4, from 6:30pm to 8:30pm at MeYou Health.

MeYou Health

6th Floor, 27-43 Wormwood St.

Boston, MA 02210


A big thank you to MeYou Health for hosting this event!

ABOUT YOUR TEACHER

Amy Chenault


At Society of Grownups, Amy is an Interaction Designer helping to tackle the challenge of how to translate the location’s emotionally rewarding, community-based experience to the digital space. In some of her other UX lives, she’s had the opportunity to collaborate with amazing teams to give local communities a voice while maintaining a newspaper’s journalistic integrity (Neighborhood Square), find new and innovative ways to get kids moving in the classroom (Pearson), and build an entirely new community platform for one of the most robust communities on the Internet (The Huffington Post). Work she has contributed to has garnered the 2011 Italian national prize for innovation, an acknowledgement prize in the 2011 Holcim awards for sustainable construction, and a 2014 CODiE nomination for Best Professional Learning Solution for Education. 


LinkedIn | Twitter



FINANCIAL NEED

A limited number of scholarships are available for those with a financial hardship. To apply, click here. Scholarship applicants will be notified shortly after the deadline. Check out this info sheet about getting course fees covered by your employer. 

Have a course voucher? Redeem it here!
results.name: Crafting the User Journey: Learning to Scaffold an Experience

results.description:
Kelly had fallen for a man. She wanted this man in her life and thought somewhere down the road, he would be calling any day. Yet, he had not called her in some time. Soon her thoughts turned to, "I never seem to hold onto the men that I truly wanted to be with". She was beginning to feel anger, fear, and loss and she acknowledged on another level that there wasn't much hope for the relationship.

Kelly was obviously strung out on the man, and she was very disconnected from the underlying pain that was driving her. Kelly’s head was just spinning in circles as she analyzed everything the man said or did and why he wasn’t with her at that time. The hurt buried within Kelly was keeping her attached to the man in a very unhealthy way…

Does this story sound familiar to you?

Struggling to find love, but no matter what you do, love always seems to evade you. Well then it is time to stop struggling an join us.

We Will:


Develop Your Intuition and Sensory Awareness

Use Your Relationships to Evolve Spiritually

Create a Healthier and More Fulfilling Relationship for you


Ellen
PSYCH-K & NLP Practitioner

results.description:
Here are just some of the things you can get out of these meetings:

• Access to thousands of dollars of courses, software, and other resources

• Advice on overcoming a business or marketing obstacle you're facing

• Accountability

• Ideas and inspiration

• Meet awesome people who enjoy talking about this stuff as much as you do

Or, you can be a fly on the wall.  No pressure at all.  Feel free to drop in to just listen and see what internet marketing really looks like from people who are actually doing it.

We try to keep the meetings to about 60 - 90 minutes.  Here's the way it works:

• 7:00pm Join the meeting here:  https://hangouts.google.com/call/dq4qhhdefftaq3fmqwij2ipe2ea.  It tends to work best with Chrome (rather than Internet Explorer or FireFox).

• Intros, and goal checking:

• New Members:  What are you working on?  And what is it you hope to get out of attending these meetings?

• Existing Members:  How'd your week go?  Did you accomplish your goals?  What are your goals for next week.

• Check-Up on last week's Couch of Insight participate:  What results did he/she get from the session?

• The Couch of Insight:  One member goes into depth on what they've been working on, telling us where they need assistance, what resources have helped them to be successful, and what strategies have been valuable.

• (Meeting Ends around 8pm officially, but usually runs late with people wanting to help the person on The Couch.)

• Chat and Offer Assistance: The Hangout will remain open until everyone leaves.  You can stay as long as you want to meet new members and give the person on The Couch any advice or feedback you may have.

Feedback

What's ONE thing that would have made this meeting better? Either let me know during the session, or you can keep it anonymous by filling out the a Survey Monkey (I'll provide the link in the session).

<a href="https://www.surveymonkey.com/r/KFNMRFX"></a>
results.how_to_find_us: Google Hangouts.  Join by clicking the link in the description.  Give it a shot before the meeting to make sure you can join without any problems.  Let me know if you're having trouble.

results.description:
I'm putting this on the calendar to let you know of a great opportunity to learn more about winter hiking from the AMC's Boston Chapter. While you can sign up here so you can communicate with other's from our group that might be going, you MUST follow the steps described below so you can register with the AMC and pay them in order to reserve a spot. This program usually sells out early so don't rely on being able to register at the door.


===============

If you plan to begin winter hiking or need to brush up on your skills I would strongly recommend the Winter Hiking and Backpacking Program being offered by the Boston Chapter of the AMC. I participated in this program years ago and still find myself referring back to the information that I learned. We will be coordinating some of our own introductory trips so be sure to watch for the trip postings. 

About the Program

The Winter Hiking Program teaches the best practices of winter hiking and backpacking in New England. Taught by AMC Boston Chapter leaders, students will have the opportunity to attend lectures, small group breakout sessions, and hands-on opportunities with winter hiking and backpacking gear.

Topics include heat management and winter hiking clothing, group hiking techniques, energy management and nutrition, winter travel and snowshoeing, winter safety and injury prevention, above tree-line hiking, non-technical use of ice axe and crampons, winter weather, camping techniques and equipment, backcountry food prep, and more. 

There will be numerous weekend trips offered exclusively or preferentially to participants in this class to put your learning into practice including a special program weekend at Cardigan Lodge on the weekend of January 23-25, 2016. This is also a great opportunity to meet lots of other people who love hiking and enjoy the outdoors!

REGISTER WITH THE AMC >>> 

https://regi.amcboston.org/996

results.description:
The first half hour to hour, we have an open discussion session. Our final hour is for the presentation: Bridging the Data Divide - Mapping JSON and XML to Objects in iOS Software (Objective-C)

Speaker: Steve Caine

Most mobile apps have a requirement to access data from remote web services in order to present information derived from that data to users. To support multiple hardware platforms, text-based encodings of this data for transmission are generally preferred over binary formats. Among these, the most common are JSON (JavaScript Object Notation) and XML (eXtensible Markup Language). But then this text must be translated back into binary data for use by the apps’ software, generally using object-oriented languages such as C++, Objective-C, or Java. Sending data back to web services requires a reverse translation.

Common problems generally lead to common solutions. A search on ‘json xml’ on GitHub.com (home to a vast trove of all kinds of open-source software) returns over 1,800 repositories offering solutions to this challenge. A search on ‘JSON’ on CocoaPods.org (site of a popular dependency manager for iOS and OS X software) returns 591 such open-source libraries, plus another 172 for a search on ‘XML’.


I’ll be describing what I learned in researching three such offerings for use in my own and clients’ apps: RestKit - https://github.com/RestKit/RestKit (which also provides networking code to access web services)

RZImport - https://github.com/raizlabs/RZImport

Mantle - https://github.com/Mantle/Mantle


As part of my research, I’ve created three open-source repositories of my own illustrating the use of each to access data on the operations of the Metropolitan Boston Transit Authority (MBTA):

https://github.com/SteveCaine/MBTA-RestKit

https://github.com/SteveCaine/MBTA-RZImport

https://github.com/SteveCaine/NextBus-Mantle

These use either data drawn from the MBTA’s own web service http://realtime.mbta.com/portal

or from that of NextBus Inc

https://www.nextbus.com/xmlFeedDocs/NextBusXMLFeed.pdf

a California company that delivers web-service access to such data from the MBTA as well as from dozens of other public transit agencies throughout North America.

Hear which of the three I finally decided to use for my own software, and why.


Our presenter this evening is Steve Caine.  Here's his description of his presentation: 

The frameworks I’m planning to demonstrate next month go further in customizing JSON/XML-to-NSDictionary/NSArray-to-custom-objects translation, allowing greater freedom in property naming and nested object trees with minimal code. 

My brief look at cocoapods.org today found 17 repos for Objective-C alone for the search:

https://cocoapods.org/?q=object%20map

so it’s a popular topic with a lot of players.

I have open-source repos on GitHub that illustrate the use of three different frameworks to access MBTA system data via JSON and XML from two different web services:

https://github.com/SteveCaine/NextBus-Mantle - using Mantle (https://github.com/Mantle/Mantle)

https://github.com/SteveCaine/MBTA-RZImport - using RZImport from Raizlabs (https://github.com/Raizlabs/RZImport)

https://github.com/SteveCaine/MBTA-RestKit - using RestKit (https://github.com/RestKit/RestKit)

I hope people will find it useful to hear me talk about my experience in implementing these demonstration projects.

results.description:
WHAT IS OUR CULTURE'S SUMMUN BONUM (GREATEST GOOD)?

Summum bonum is a Latin expression meaning "the highest good", which was introduced by Cicero, to correspond to the Idea of the Good or ultimate end in Ancient Greek philosophy. The summum bonum is generally thought of as being an end in itself, and at the same time as containing all other goods. The term was used in medieval philosophy and in Kantianism, to describe the necessity of having an ultimate importance, a singular and overriding end, which all human beings ought to pursue and that is connected to our ultimate happiness. 


Does our culture have a greatest good or end? If so, what is it, and how does it effect the way we live our lives and engage in community? If not, why not....and how does it's absence effect our lives and community?

Come join the discussion!
results.how_to_find_us: We'll be in the back booth at Rosebud Cafe in Davis Square from 7-9pm. Tell the hostess that you're there for the Meetup Group and they will show you to our table.
results.name: What is our Culture's "Summum Bonum" (Greatest Good and Goal)?

results.description:
Welcome to the weekly BKBS Wednesday meet up. Please join us at 7:00 PM by the 3rd table station in the middle of the top roping / lead area. If you are still by the bouldering wall, keep on walking.

We usually meet there for about 10 mins, and then team up in groups of 2 or 3 for top-rope climbing.

If you know that you'll be late, let us know in the comments section, and maybe tell us what you'll be wearing, so we can look out for you. 

BKBS (http://www.bkbsomerville.com/Classes/. If you have a working knowledge of how to belay, you will need to be belay certified before climbing on the ropes. Please flag down a BKBS employee and let them know you need to take a belay test. To pass such a test you will need to display how to tie a double figure eight knot with a fisherman's backup, safely belay a climber up a wall, catch them on a fall, and lower them to the ground safely.

What equipment do I need?  You will need at the bare minimum a harness and climbing shoes. Rentals are available. Grigri devices are provided at every station.

What if I can come, but at a different time?  Just let everyone know you want to climb at a different time and use the community to find a partner for those dates / times.

These are the climbing rates:

ADMISSION (Full day use, you can leave and come back!): 

Day Pass - $25 (Students $20) 
10 Pack - $225 (Students $180)

(Membership Pricing also available)

RENTALS: 

Shoes - $5 
Harness - $5 
Chalk Bag - $2 
Full Gear Kit - $11

results.description:
Hi All, On November 4th at 7pm we're going to have an off-schedule meetup at Localytics (not at Akamai!). It's very important that you RSVP here if you want to come - I'll give details below. But first, we have a really nice talk scheduled.

7:30: Julian Arni - Servant - A type level DSL for web APIs

For Servant, a web framework is just an interpreter of a DSL for describing web APIs. We'll see the benefits this approach confers, in terms of clarity, succinctness and safety. We'll also see other interpretations that are possible of this same DSL, which provide client functions in a variety of languages, documentation, mock servers, and other things.

-------

Logistics: I need to put everyone's name on the guest list, so if you plan on coming, please RSVP and/or email me your first and last name. Location: Localytics is at 101 Arch St, but the main entrance is on Summer St. across from Macy's. Once inside, take the escalator up to the next floor, and visit the security desk. Myself or one of my coworkers will be there to let people in. We'll then take the elevator up to the 8th floor. We'll start at 7:30 to wait for people who have trouble finding us.

Food and Free Beer: We'll have pizzas, and we have 4 kegs in the office :) 

Other info: Localytics is a nice space that we can use for lots of different types of events like off-schedule meetups, Haskell coding and/or teaching sessions, office hours, etc. It will be great for people to come and see, and get ideas on how we could utilize it.
results.name: Special Meetup: Julian Arni on Servant

results.description: "I appeal to you, brothers, by the name of our Lord Jesus Christ, that all of you agree, and that there be no divisions among you, but that you be united in the same mind and the same judgment."  Perhaps one of the most troubled churches we see in the New Testament while also being one of the most blessed, Corinth is an example of God's grace not to give up on a struggling church, as well as an example of how to be the church God wants.  1 (and 2!) results.description:
Join the Boston Austrian Economics Group as we embark upon Chapters 2 & 3, of Part 1, in the Austrian classic; "Human Action: A Treatise on Economics," by Ludwig von Mises. The group will discuss the weekly readings and questions.

Please note that the readings are not required to attend our meeting, but are recommended. As always, anyone interested in economics is welcome.

Tony C's Sports Bar and Grill has plenty of parking and is accessible via the Orange Line "Assembly" stop. READINGS:

Chapter 2: The Epistemological Problems of the Sciences of Human Action Chapter 3: Economics and the Revolt Against Reason

QUESTIONS:

1) What are the two main branches of the sciences of human action?

2) Mises states that the fundamental logical relations are not subject to proof or disproof, but why?

3) Does action imply that it attains the end aimed at?

4) Can a collective whole act, why or why not?

5) What are the two aspects of every action?

6) Why is action always speculation?

7) What is the primary tool for acting man?

8) Which group was responsible for the modern revolt against reason, and which tactic did they use?

9) What motivated Marx to create the term “polylogism, and why did Mises strongly object to this notion?

10) Do different races have different logical structures of mind?

11) What determines the judgments of value and the choice of ends? 

12) Can we study a science of irrationality?

Happy reading, see you soon!
results.name: THE REVOLT AGAINST REASON AND THE HUMAN ACTION SCIENCE PROBLEM
