results.description:
(Please note our new RSVP policy below.) 


We are a casual group of people who enjoy playing complex board games -- the kind of board games that make you think. We play a variety of games, most of which are Euro style games of medium complexity.  Games often last 90 minutes or more and involve juggling a lot of rules and factors in your head, to decide what to do.  However, there's also plenty of laughter and friendship involved.  If that sounds up your alley, we hope you'll join us. 

Our weekly meetup is in a TERRIFIC space for games steps from the Kendall Square T, with easy parking, and lots of room to spread out in.  Full directions are below.  The building door does get locked in the evening, but there is plenty of foot traffic in and out.  If you expect to arrive later than 8:30, send Tucker a message earlier in the day, and we'll make sure someone is there to let you in.

Our meetups happen once a week (alternating Mondays and Wednesdays), from 7:00 pm onwards.  Our group has been running since 2007, and we have a large crowd of regulars as well as new members each week.

BEANTOWN GAMERS RSVP POLICY:

1. You must RSVP to attend.

2. Please be considerate of others -- only RSVP if you are likely to attend.

3. If you need to cancel your RSVP, please do so at least 24 hours before the event.  This allows enough notice for someone else to use your spot.

4. If you would like to come but there are no spots, send Tucker a message.  You might also consider attending our alternative "Light Game Night" a few steps away at Cosi Cafe.

5. We know everyone has emergencies.  But consistent, inconsiderate use of RSVPs -- which includes being a "no show", cancelling in the last 48 hours, or frequently cancelling RSVPs -- will lead to being removed from the group.  Sorry, we still like you, it's just not fair to everyone else!

6. If you use a "+1" spot, all of the above applies to you and your +1.  Since you are using two spots, it is extra important that you are considerate about it.

NEW MEMBERS: Welcome!  We look forward to meeting you.  If you want to bring a friend, please have them sign up with their own account rather than using a +1.  Unfortunately, we've gotten a lot of no-show +1's from first time attendees, so we don't accept those anymore.  Sorry!


We play whatever people bring, which typically includes a lot of Euros.  Here's a "tip of the iceberg" look at a few games that have been popular lately:

7 Wonders, Terra Mystica, Race for the Galaxy, Splendor, One Night Werewolf, Le Havre, Hansa Teutonica, Machi Koro, Concordia, Super Big Boggle

As you can see, there is some real variety.  A few of our regular attendees bring about 20-30 games between them, so there's always a lot to choose from.  But if you have a game you like, just bring it with you!

If you haven't played these kind of games before, but think you'll like them, you're welcome too!  But be aware that you are NOT likely to find traditional American games (like Monopoly, Sorry, Risk, or Poker); heavy strategy or negotiation games (like 18xx, wargames, or Diplomacy); or pure abstract games (like Chess).

Finally, a note about Settlers of Catan, Carcassonne, and Ticket to Ride.  These are traditional "gateway games" that many people play when they first discover Euros.  Although you will occasionally find those games at our meetups, many of us have played them to death and have become more interested in games with a little more complexity to them.

Update (10/15): In order to accommodate more people in the room, and maintain an easygoing environment for conversation and game playing, we ask that you please save loud games (like those with real-time arguing) for later in the evening, when the room is less full.  Typically this means 9:30 or later.

OUTBOUND (from Boston / from Park Street)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the front of the train. Cross the street. (If you take the escalator up, turn around first to see the street.) After crossing, proceed behind the T entrance (perpendicular to Main Street).  Building E25 is the brick building a quarter block down, across from the parking lot.

INBOUND (from Alewife / Porter / Harvard / Central)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the rear of the train. Take the stairs or elevator straight up. Proceed straight ahead (perpendicular to Main Street). Building E25 is the brick building a quarter block down, across from the parking lot.

FROM BOSTON (or Memorial Drive)
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading north (cross the river if coming from Boston).  Memorial Drive is the first cross street past the river; go past it.
2) Take the first right, onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the first right after Memorial Drive.)
3) Take the first right, onto Main St.
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical. Exit the parking lot at the rear (opposite from where you entered). Building E25 will be directly across the street.

FROM CAMBRIDGE (or points west)
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading south.
2) Take a left onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the last left before Memorial Drive; there is a railroad crossing there.)
3) Take the first right, onto Main St.
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical. Exit the parking lot at the rear (opposite from where you entered). Building E25 will be directly across the street.

Once you enter, Room 119 is just past the stairs on the right. There is a suggested donation of $1.00 that goes towards site fees and party supplies.  (When we have a raffle, you will also receive an extra raffle ticket as thanks for donating.)

Feel free to email with any questions -- we hope to see you at a meetup soon.
results.how_to_find_us: Walk a quarter of a block from the Kendall T, in the opposite direction from the Marriott Plaza. We're in the big building on your right (across from the parking lot). When you enter, our room is just across the foyer and on your right.
results.name: Wednesday Game Night

results.description:
This is our brand new auxiliary meetup event.  This is a great opportunity to socialize and play games in a relaxed environment -- and best of all, there's no cap on attendance.

For this first ever light game night, we'll be raffling off one or more games (depending on attendance) to those who come!

We are a casual group of people who enjoy playing complex board games -- the kind of board games that make you think. We play a variety of games, but the games at this particular event are going to be on the smaller side -- because those are often the games that work best in a cafe setting.

Our main meetup requires RSVPs due to heavy popularity and limited space.  This event runs simultaneously, two buildings away.  RSVPs are NOT required for this event.  RSVPs are still appreciated so the event hosts know how many people to expect, but you don't need to update them and can come even if you don't RSVP.

This event takes place once a week (alternating Mondays and Wednesdays), from 7:00 - 9:30 or 10.  Cosi closes at 10, but after 9:30, you are welcome to come and join the regular meetup at that point, no RSVP required.

Cosi Cafe has graciously allowed us to use their back seating area every week.  You are not required to buy anything from them, but their food is honestly pretty good, so please take advantage of them if you are hungry for dinner, soft drinks, or snacks.

We play whatever people bring, but you don't have to bring anything -- the hosts will always have a bag of games with them!  Some games that you might expect to see here include:

Red 7, Love Letter, Codenames, Pictomania, The Resistance, Avalon, One Night Ultimate Werewolf, Bang!, Glory to Rome, Innovation, Mottainai, Chrononaughts, Time Lines, Tash-Kalar

If you haven't played these kind of games before, but think you'll like them, you're welcome too!  But be aware that you are NOT likely to find traditional American games (like Monopoly, Sorry, Risk, or Poker); heavy strategy or negotiation games (like 18xx, wargames, or Diplomacy); or pure abstract games (like Chess).  And if you're looking for longer or larger Euros (like 7 Wonders, Puerto Rico, or Terra Mystica), check out our regular "Game Night" meetup.

OUTBOUND (from Boston / from Park Street)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the front of the train. Cross the street. (If you take the escalator up, turn around first to see the street.) After crossing, turn left and walk about 20 feet to Cosi.

INBOUND (from Alewife / Porter / Harvard / Central)
Take the Red Line to Kendall Square station. Exit at the gates at the rear of the train. Take the stairs up, then up again towards the busy street, which is Main Street.  Turn left and walk about 20 feet to Cosi.

FROM BOSTON (or Memorial Drive) 
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading north (cross the river if coming from Boston).  Memorial Drive is the first cross street past the river; go past it. 
2) Take the first right, onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the first right after Memorial Drive.) 
3) Take the first right, onto Main St. 
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical.
5) One side of the parking lot has a bunch of buildings with a handicapped ramp leading into it.  Go up the ramp, through the walkway, and Cosi will be right next to you when you come out.

FROM CAMBRIDGE (or points west) 
1) Take Massachusetts Ave heading south. 
2) Take a left onto Vassar St.  (Vassar is the last left before Memorial Drive; there is a railroad crossing there.) 
3) Take the first right, onto Main St. 
4) Pass two signals, then turn right onto Hayward.  You may park in the parking lot on the right side of Hayward.  An MIT parking permit is NOT required in the evening, but please do not park in the spaces marked Medical.
5) One side of the parking lot has a bunch of buildings with a handicapped ramp leading into it.  Go up the ramp, through the walkway, and Cosi will be right next to you when you come out.

results.description:
Mineral deficiency is rampant in our society – contributing to a whole host of chronic and acute illnesses. Depleted soils mean that our fruits and vegetables don’t have the same mineral content that they once had. To make things worse, we no longer favor mineral-rich foods in our diets: organ meats, seaweed, and bone broths are not exactly staples in most families’ menus. They should be, because mineral rich broths and soups are important nutritive remedies in every traditional healing system!

Grandma knows this, which is why she would always make her special, from scratch, chicken soup when we got sick. Full of onions, garlic, thyme, sage, oregano and chicken, cooked in a base of mineral rich chicken broth. Her soup is packed with nutrition, immune support, and antimicrobial plants; just the thing we need when feeling under the weather.

In this class, come join us as we learn how to make a basic bone broth, and turn that broth into all kinds of soups, stews, and other recipes. Find out where to get good quality bones, how to cook them up, and why bone broths are one of the most important-yet-forgotten foods that we should be eating daily.

Wednesday, November 4th, 2015
7:00 – 9:00pm
25 St. Mary’s Court, Brookline

The fee for this class is $20.

RSVP by emailing us at [masked], or calling[masked]-5274.
results.name: Herbal and Nourishing Broths

results.description:
Marie Manis is the MA Campaign Manger for Compassion and Choices.

About Compassion and Choices (from http://compassionandchoices.org/who-we-are/about):

Compassion & Choices is the leading nonprofit organization committed to helping everyone have the best death possible. We offer free consultation, planning resources, referrals and guidance, and across the nation we work to protect and expand options at the end of life.

For over thirty years we have reduced people’s suffering and given them some control in their final days – even when injury or illness takes their voice. We are experts in what it takes to die well.

Compassion & Choices works with individuals and allied organizations throughout America to:

* Make aid in dying an open, legitimate option recognized throughout the medical field and permitted in more states.

* Increase patient control and reduce unwanted interventions at the end of life.

* Pass additional laws ensuring full information and access to all end-of-life care options.

* Normalize accurate, unbiased language throughout the end-of-life choice discussion (“aid in dying” instead of “assisted suicide”).

* Establish aid in dying as a prime motivator in voter decision-making.

* Support the expansion of the end-of-life choice movement and exert a leadership role in it.


General Information

Our First Wednesday Dialog series brings in outside speakers to share interesting topics related to Humanism -- kind of like Ted Talk. We socialize and enjoy refreshments until about 7:15, at which point the speakers presents for as long as they choose, usually until 8:00 or so. At this point we pass the mic around and have a group discussion about the topic. When the discussion wraps up, we continue with more refreshments and socializing until around 9:00 when all attendees are welcome to join our open steering committee meeting.

We  take donations at the door to cover the cost of the meeting ($5 is suggested). Half of the donations (after we pay the rent) are given as an honorarium to the speaker. All regular attendees are encouraged to bring refreshments to share.

Note that we have a large mailing list outside of Meetup.com so the RSVP numbers are generally much lower than the actual attendance.

results.description:
This month's performers:

Become Lovable Problem Child, Fable Grazer, Forbes Graham, Long Blonde Wig, Metal Chaos Ensemble, Ordinylitenhauer, Parma Chai...and, maybe you?

** All Ages / $5-10 Sliding Scale **

“What is Sonic Osmosis?”

Ask me tomorrow and you may get a different answer. Today, Sonic Osmosis is a playground for Improvised Music. If you ever met Improvised Music, you know she has a free spirit. She doesn’t like being told what to play, when to play, or whom to play with. Sadly, many venues don’t have the patience to indulge Improvised Music and her whimsical ways. “Sell more drinks!” they scream at her. Thank [higher power] for Out of the Blue Too Gallery!

Once a month (or so), we book a handful of groups and solo performers who have made the foolhardy choice to court this lovely, impetuous muse. Each group/artist plays at least one 10-20 minute set, at some point during the night -- no set times, because of course, Improvised Music would scoff at the idea.

Mixed in between these sets, we shake it up! Hopefully you aced AP Statistics, because any permutation is possible in these untethered moments. Members of different groups might form an impromptu ensemble; two or more groups might fuse into a super-group in a brilliant stellar collision…

And maybe…bold audience members, who came with noise-makers in tow, step into the playground and add their verse to our collective ode. Don’t worry -- no one will pressure you to participate, for the muse surely would not approve.

Hopefully, by the end of the night we have expanded our vocabulary, sensitivity, and imagination, had some fun and satisfied our insatiable muse!

If you’ve still got questions about what this is all about, my name is Marc, leave me a message! I may or may not have answers, for I cannot claim to fully understand this ethereal temptress…
results.name: Sonic Osmosis #4: Free Improv Hootenanny

Limelight Comedy Club is back Wednesday, November 4 with headliner Brian Barganier. Brian has been headlining all over the country bringing stability to the ever growing DIY comedy scene. His comedy has been featured on Comedy Central, (Writer for CC: SOCIALSCENE) MTV, (MTV2's Guy Code, 2015 Bae Day Special, Greatest Party Story Ever and many cameos) Cartoon Network's Adult Swim, AXS TV (Tom Green Live). He also is on the tv show Little Women: NY (Lifetime). He released a full length cd/DVD I'll Regret This (2015) produced by the Slow Mutants Productions. Brian is a member of the skit group JPD Entertainment which has been featured on HBO's series "Sex/Now" and was the winner of New England's Funniest Comedian at Mohegan Sun Casino (2013) Brian Has worked alongside Pablo Francisco, Amy Schumer, Nick DiPaolo, amongst many names. The Connecticut native's style runs comfortably on the edge of conventional and alternative comedy. He is described mostly as what can only be called "planned carelessness," Although he is seen as being morbid or crude sometimes, Brian always manages to pull a 180 and find the funny in topics that sometimes seem untouchable.

Featuring on this show will be the hysterical Wes Hazard. A New England native & named 1 of “5 Boston Comedians to Watch” by the Boston Globe, Wes loves to entertain with his wit, energy, & storytelling. He wishes you only the best.

Also on this show will be:
Drew Dunn
Andy Ostroff
Dylan Krasinski
& More!

Doors open at 7 pm, show at 8pm.

results.description:
Reservations are REQUIRED and you can ONLY make a reservation by sending email to [masked]. (RSVPing here doesn't count.) $18 at the door ($5 for students).

Ben and Joe have been playing together for almost 5 years, the last 3 of which sent them to the Port Townsend Acoustic Blues Festival, learning at the feet of the elders of the acoustic blues tradition. They found an affinity in the many branches that tied into the blues and created this duo as a way to explore these branches. Their musical kinship and sense of joy in interpreting this music is evident and was the basis of an invitation Dom Flemons (formerly of the Carolina Chocolate Drops) to form his band when he went solo. Ben and Joe joined Dom on his recent album, Prospect Hill, and toured the US with him, furthering their knowledge of Anglo and African American music traditions. Rather than thinking of their music as blues, it’s best to situate Ben and Joe (and Dom) as American songsters. A songster traditionally refers to an African-American artist whose repertoire is much broader than the old blues, and spans many of the genres that Ben and Joe Inhabit. Big Bill Broonzy and Mississippi John Hurt are classic examples of songsters. Whatever you want to call it, Ben Hunter & Joe Seamons make American music. They make music that hews to the rough-and-tumble collisions of musical inspirations from the early 20th century; music that paved the way for everything we enjoy today.

The songs on their new album, Take Yo Time, tap into everything from the hokum jug bands of Gus Cannon and the Memphis Sheiks, to country blues masters Reverend Gary Davis, Robert Johnson, and Blind Willie McTell. They also touch on ancient English ballads like House Carpenter, Appalachian murder ballads like the classic Tom Dooley, and the early jazz compositions of Shelton Brooks and Duke Ellington. All of these traditions are tied together in the swirling musical whirlpool of pre-war American music. With a well-rosined fiddle and an old banjo, Ben Hunter & Joe Seamons are tracing these backroads, bringing the songs back to life.
results.name: Ben Hunter and Joe Seamons house concert

results.description:
Join us for an evening shooting in around Boston Harbor with help and advice from Ian.

The workshop will run from 7.30pm and will end around 11pm (you may leave sooner if you need to).

The class will be limited to just 8 and there will be a $35 charge.

You will need a tripod and a cable/shutter release (the self timer is not a suitable option).

Learn how to make darkness look like daylight and how to make the darkness look really black. Learn how to set the correct exposure and how to create those stRburst effects in your photograph. 

We may also cover some light painting techniques. 

We will end around 11pm.

There is parking in around South Station for as little as $10 -$15

The group is limited in size to ensure everyone gets attention.
results.name: Boston at Night

results.description:
Join 50 to 80 or 100 dancers any Wednesday at Dance Freedom!!

We are the original barefoot weekly dance, continuously running for 44 years, that has spawned hundreds if not thousands of other dances around the world.

In a drug, alcohol, and shoe-free environment, we've been making friends and sharing safe and juicy dances for decades. Come join the fun!! Discover the joy of dancing in a totally non-judgmental atmosphere, where anything safe and respectful goes... dance by yourself, in a group, with a same or opposite sex partner, or even just chat and enjoy watching.

First time visitors are welcomed heartily, and get in for half price! Otherwise, you decide what to pay in a range from $10 to $20, or less later in the evening as the event nears its end (information on late admission discounts is at the door). Our friendly dancers range from utterly new at it to very skilled dancers in funk, rock, salsa, modern, jazz, hip-hop, African & Latin and swing, tango, contact improvisation, and our own unique spontaneous creations! Dance with or alongside amazing dancers from local dance troupes as well as with ordinary good-hearted rug cutters. At work they may be doctors, lawyers, programmers, massage therapists, expressive therapists, artists, students, dog walkers, scientists, or anything else, but at heart they all love to dance.

The music runs the gamut: funk, world music, soul & r&b, house, trance, hip-hop, salsa, yoga music, jazz or swing, reggae, disco, you name it! Each DJ from our rotating list has a unique style, but we try to include something for everyone in every set. We keep a good balance in the music: familiar with unusual, timeless with current, melodic with drum-based, and positive lyrics with instrumentals--in all kinds of rhythms & styles! In any given evening, the world music parts of our dance are likely to include at least 3 or so of the following... African, Latin, Indian, Middle Eastern, Caribbean, zydeco, gypsy and much more. You'll hear everything from basic party music to very danceable songs with socially conscious lyrics, but you won't be hearing anything sexist, racist, violent, hating or otherwise divisive.

Start with a soothing stretch and warm up at 7:30, connect with the group and start to boogie at 7:50 with our first DJ of the evening, take a brief break at 8:50 for community announcements and a short unique performance or workshop (or chatting & stretching in a way that doesn't interfere), then cut the rug again by 9:15 at the latest with the evening's second DJ, till 10:30--plenty of time for a great workout and some feel-good inspiration and respiration and perspiration!

At the beginning of each half of the evening's music, everyone who wants to gathers around a centerpiece to hold hands, and dance in a winding chain together to a song with uplifting, connective (or at least beautiful and hypnotic) slow to medium tempo rhythms. (This dance was created from out of a drumming circle on the Cambridge Common in the sixties, after all, and some of that great political and community spirit still lives on here.) Then, it's all dance music, generally building in tempo to a crescendo, slowing down again for some more melodic and slow dance songs for a few minutes, then gradually building to a second crescendo. The second half of the evening's dance follows roughly the same pattern with a different DJ and style, and ends with another circle dance for those who enjoy it.

Dancers are always welcome to help with set-up or take-down, and get in free for doing so! It's a great chance to get to know the community better and be serviceful, as well as to save money and help us to be around for another 42 years... Welcome! For more information, E-mail: [masked]
results.how_to_find_us: Opposite the Cambridge Common, see the Sheraton Hotel w/the big red letters COMMANDER on top.  Enter the stone church just left of hotel, @ entrance closest to hotel.  Follow the hall straight, left and right to the desk to sign in.
results.name: Dance Freedom 11/4 Dj's Rose and Steve

RoLa Languages Institute is planning to have a great time with all those who have an interest in speaking English. There will be many native English speakers so you can practice your English, learn from fellow students and teachers as well as <a>make friends</a>!

For whom?

Everyone who has any interest in English, from beginner students to native speakers.


When?

results.description:
Ellen Jaffe JonesThe Veg Coach

Creative Cook / Author / Consultant
From our test kitchen to your home kitchen

OK, show of hands.  How many of you eat quinoa as a side dish?
Most cooks use the protein-rich grain as a substitute for rice.
But, I've got a treat for you today.  It's a recipe for Quinoa crisp chocolate balls!
What a way to reward yourself for following a healthy lifestyle.

Find it below.

Consider this too as a tasty approach to getting people interested in coming to one of my FREE cooking classes. This week, Wednesday at 9pm EST, I'll be doing a free class prepping and serving 2 recipes from my book "Eat Vegan on $4 a Day." Bring any questions to our Google Hangout: 

https://plus.google.com/events/c0oegddjuh07utbrq1mv6vm1rfg

Happy cooking,

Ellen Jaffe Jones
The Veg Coach
http://www.vegcoach.com

Buy my books:

Paleo Vegan

Eat Vegan on $4 a Day

Kitchen Divided - Vegan Recipes for Semi-Vegan Households

This is a Quinoa crisp chocolate bar you might find at your local health food store.  
But, my recipe lets you create your own Quinoa chocolate treat.  

It'll satisfy your chocolate cravings and it's so easy to make.  

The recipe is below.

You're Going to Love This!  

Quinoa Crisp Chocolate Treats
by Ellen Jaffe Jones

INGREDIENTS 

1 cup vegan chocolate chips
1/2 cup puffed quinoa
4 teaspoons coconut oil
1/8 teaspoon salt (optional)

PREPARATION INSTRUCTIONS

1 cup vegan chocolate chips
1/2 cup puffed quinoa
4 teaspoons coconut oil
1/8 teaspoon salt (optional)

Melt chocolate chips in a double-boiler, or place in a microwave-safe bowl and heat for about 60 seconds until the chips develop a slight sheen.  
Place all ingredients in a medium pot (or add to the double-boiler) and over medium heat, and stir constantly for about 5 minutes taking care not to burn the chocolate. 
Form small balls and place on a non-stick cookie sheet.  
Refrigerate for at least 60 minutes before serving.  
For those wanting to reduce fat intake, this can be made without the coconut oil, but make sure the chocolate chips are completely melted.

FIND MORE RECIPES

Follow on Instagram

results.description:
Tune in at http://www.philosophicperspectives.com

I had the pleasure of viewing the documentary film, "Who Killed the Electric Car?"  with the Social Philosophizers Club very recently, and I found it such a rich source of insight into the politics and economics of American society that I will dig deeper into the subject during this show. The film's subtitle, "A lack of consumer confidence... or conspiracy?" suggests two elements of the demise of the electric car's apparent ascendancy in California in the opening years of the new millennia. My own take, however, is that the bigger factor is CONSPIRACY.


</a>

Who Killed the Electric Car? is a 2006 documentary film that explores the creation, limited commercialization, and subsequent destruction of the battery electric vehicle in the United States, specifically the General Motors EV1 of the mid-1990s. The film explores the roles of automobile manufacturers, the oil industry, the U.S. government, the California government, batteries, hydrogen vehicles, and consumers in limiting the development and adoption of this technology.

After a premiere at the Sundance Film Festival, it was released theatrically by Sony Pictures Classics in June, 2006 and then on DVD by Sony Pictures Home Entertainment on November 14, 2006.

The sequel:"Revenge of the Electric Car,"  had its world premiere at the 2011 Tribeca Film Festival on Earth Day, April 22, 2011.  (<a href="https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Who_Killed_the_Electric_Car%3F">Wikipedia)

********************

Your RSVP indicates that you plan on listening to the show. After listening to the broadcast or the subsequently posted podcast you will  be able to post comments on this page. (No, Cyberville MA is not a real place! But I look forward to "seeing" you on the radio, November 4, 2015, 10pm Eastern/7pm Pacific.)


Philosophic Perspectives with Arthur D. Schwartz. Visit the show page at: http://www.philosophicperspectives.com
results.name: Who Killed the Electric Car? Reflections on Chris Paine's Powerful Documentary.

Mark your calendars for the next Community Table happening in the Branchfood space!


The November Community Table will be part of Impact Hub's Food for Thought series. The Food for Thought lunch and learn discussions will occur every day of the City Awake Festival in different locations around the city. In support of this social impact festival scheduled Nov 4-14, the November Community Table will include discussion on social impact initiatives in the food system and the emerging support networks that exist for these startups and others.

Community Table is for eaters, entrepreneurs, and students of food to connect and exchange ideas. A model created by Babson's Food Sol, the design is always one table, one conversation, with the collective driving the content. People have reported finding partners, expanding networks, and reaching retail all as a direct result of attending Community Table. 

We hope you'll join the conversation to network, discuss, connect and learn from others doing awesome work in the city!


See you there! 

Lauren, Sarah, and Ally @ Branchfood

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball. 

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.
results.name: Thursday Lunchtime Soccer (OUTDOOR)

results.description:
VOLUNTEERING for $2/bag of produce in Jamaica Plain
Do NOT sign up UNLESS you are willing to work hard for about 2 hours.
Others can attend each week and carry home a $2 bag of vegetables and fruits.

Alternate Thursdays from 3:00 -- 4:00 PM
[Volunteers arrive 30 minutes earlier and stay up to 30 minutes after close.]
[Those getting bags of produce can expect to retrieve them from 3-4 pm.]
From May 28 onward

IF THERE's ANY QUESTION about the DATE, call FAIR FOODS in Dorchester: www.FairFoods.org

Amory Street Building
125 Amory Street
(22 Bus toward Ruggles)
Jamaica Plain
Boston, MA 02130
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Amory Street Building at 125 Amory Street in Jamaica Plain,
Boston, MA 02130

Between Jackson Square and Stony Brook MBTA Orange Line stops.
Near Dimock and Atherton Streets.

The Amory PACE Center is a comprehensive service center and residential apartment complex for frail elders and persons with disabilities.

Boston Housing Authority (BHA) recently completed a $4 million renovation at 125A Amory Street, a formerly dilapidated structure behind the Amory Street Elderly/Disabled public housing development.

The community is now supported by a full-service center for elderly and disabled residents over the age of 55. The Center is operated by the Upham’s Corner Health Center through its Elder Service Plan-PACE (Program of All-inclusive Care for Elders). PACE is a community-based, comprehensive initiative providing medical, adult day health and supportive care for frail elders that allows them to remain living independently in the community rather than in a nursing home.

• http://jamaicaplaingazette.com/2013/06/07/new-senior-health-center-serves-125-amory-housing/

• https://www.bostonhousing.org/en/Departments/Planning-and-Real-Estate-Development/Amory-PACE-Center.aspx

In Massachusetts, PACE programs operate under the Executive Office of Elder Affairs. This is the first PACE site in the Amory neighborhood, with two other sites in Boston.

This six-story, elevator-equipped building has approximately 181 units in studio, one-bedroom or two-bedroom.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
VOLUNTEER for biweekly Thursday afternoon $2/bag of produce in Jamaica Plain, held on ALTERNATE WEEKS

When you volunteer, YOU will ALSO TAKE HOME one or two of those "$2 bags"!

Fair Foods provides a 20-22 bag of produce for the Jamaica Plain neighbors so they can eat the way I do - on produce. The neighbors only need to pay' $2 for the bag.

Volunteers unload the truck, set up portable banquet tables, set up the food in order of density (potatoes on bottom - tomatoes and bananas and berries and kale on top), then fill each bag (and 'stack' them upright by one another - for the 'paying neighbors' to pick up (for $2).

We arrive around 2:30 pm (maybe as late as 2:45 pm) and work until 4:30 pm (can leave as early as 4:15 pm if we've finished all our work).

In the FRONT of the Amory Street Building at 125 Amory Street in Jamaica Plain.

Wear comfortable clothing.
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Alternate Thursdays, from 3:00 - 4:00 pm
Reserve FIRST before just showing up.
[Volunteers arrive 30 minutes earlier and stay up to 30 minutes after close]
From May 28 onward
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~ 
Bring friends! Forward the invitation to others!
Invite FRIENDS through the Facebook, LinkedIn, and Twitter 'share' buttons 
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Want to volunteer at a DIFFERENT location OR just stop by and get bread and produce?

Then check out this website and find a site that is more convenient to your location and schedule:

http://www.fairfoods.org/dollarbag.html

Volunteers MUST register in advance with phone and e-mail AND commit to work the full 2 hours (2:30-4:30 pm), but it probably won't be that long.

I am doing a meetup on Irani films at a Persian (Irani) restaurant! It is a relatively cheap restaurant and most dishes can be shared but it's cash only! 

We will be talking about A Separation by Asghar Farhadi and optional is Persepolis by Marjane Satrapi. 

Set in contemporary Iran, A Separation is a compelling drama about the dissolution of a marriage. Persepolis is an animated black and white film. The movie is based on Marjane Satrapi's childhood living in Iran and Europe. 

Persepolis is a great animated telling of Marjane Satrapi's experiences growing up in Iran and Europe. Her story is amazing view into what it was like for one family living through the tumultuous time in Iran. 

Comment on any other Irani film you would recommend. 

Accessing the films: Both A Separation and Persepolis can be rented on on Netflix DVD or rented on Amazon Prime for $2.99.
results.name: Persian (Irani) Films!

results.description:
Join us for dinner (barefoot friendly restaurant) with Sue Kenney, author of My Camino and her journey to Spain walking the Camino barefoot. Good chance to mingle and chat about her barefoot walk and writing about it and her life experience with this.
After being suddenly downsized from her corporate career, Sue Kenney wasn’t sure what to do with her life. A world masters rowing champion and mother of 3 teenagers, she left her ordinary world to embark on a spiritual journey as a simple pilgrim. She walked 500 miles over 29 days across the north of Spain on a medieval pilgrimage called the Camino de Santiago. She went alone, in the winter and returned home with a vision to share the idea of the Camino as a metaphor of a life journey with purpose. It was through the art of storytelling, she found her voice. Sue embraced a barefoot lifestyle at home and on the Camino. Join us to hear Sue’s stories and insights into this life changing experience. www.suekenney.ca
results.name: Dinner in Harvard Square with author Sue Kenney

The 13th Annual Boston Latino International Film Festival is looking for volunteers! 

We have four volunteers recruitment meetings (November 3rd and 5th) ; the actual Festival will be on Nov 18th to 21st.

results.description:
How Nature Can Save Us – Event link HERE. 


Free and open to the public. Free parking at 52 Oxford Street. 

Thursday, November 5, 6pm

Geological Lecture Hall, 24 Oxford Street

:: :: ::

M. Sanjayan, Executive Vice President and Senior Scientist, Conservation International

We live in the Anthropocene, the age of humans, and not since cyanobacteria transformed Earth’s early atmosphere has one species - Homo sapiens - had such an outsized influence on the diversity of life on the planet. Saving nature in the human age is a challenging proposition, but perhaps a more relevant question might be how nature can save humankind. In an epic journey across 24 countries accompanied by a film crew from PBS and National Geographic, Sanjayan compiled awe-inspiring stories that illuminate the inextricable link between the environment and human beings. In this program, he will discuss his journey and the basic truth it revealed: that saving nature is really about saving ourselves.

Presented in collaboration with the Harvard College Conservation Society.

Presentation and interview. This program is located at the Geological Lecture Hall, 24 Oxford Street.
results.name: Can Nature Save Us?

results.description:
We gather every month for engaging presentations and lively discussions! This group gives UX researchers in the Greater Boston community the chance to interact with each other more frequently. Each event features three speakers to talk about something a good designer finds interesting along with discussions about UX processes, techniques and much more!

1. Meeting at the Intersection of UX Design and Content Strategy (6:35-7:00)

By Marli Mesibov | LinkedIn | Twitter

Let’s talk about content strategy. Let’s talk about UX design. Let’s talk about real-world experiences. In this talk we’ll look at six scenarios where UX and content strategy combine to make our work better and our lives easier. Attendees will learn when to pull content strategy into a UX design project, some content strategy "quick wins" that UX designers can implement, UX questions to ask at the start of every project, and what to do when a UX project feels stuck in the mud.

About Marli. Marli Mesibov is a content strategist with a passion for the user experience. Her work spans websites, web applications, and mobile for enterprise companies and startups across the country. She is currently the Director of Content Strategy at Mad*Pow, a design agency in Boston with a focus on designing for people. Marli is the managing editor at UX Booth, and a frequent conference speaker. She can also be found on Twitter, where she shares thoughts on UX design, content strategy, and Muppets. You can learn more about Marli and her work at http://marli.us


2. Content & UX Go Together Like PB&J (7:00-7:25)

By Caroline Roberts | Linkedin | Twitter

By Krista Siniscarco | Linkedin | Twitter

</a> Not unlike peanut butter and jelly, content strategy and user experience design can be consumed separately—but the results are so much tastier when you put them together. This presentation will cover how the PB&J strategy took shape in two, very different, projects: <a href="http://medicineandthemilitary.com/">one an information-heavy site for medical students and physicians and the other an entertainment site that promoted a TV movie. The content strategist and UX designer will talk about their collaboration, their process for each case study, how their approach changed between projects, how they came to form their successful partnership, and what they have learned along the way.

About Caroline. Caroline Roberts is currently senior content manager at Mullen Lowe Boston, where she works on such brands as the Department of Defense, Ernst & Young, the National Geographic Channel, and PepsiCo. Before joining an ad agency, Caroline worked for Fidelity Investments, and she managed the Careers & Money and Technology channels for how-to website Life123.com. In a past life, she supervised writers and content managers for a video search service in San Francisco, where she also indexed and managed content for AOL, the NFL, and PBS. Since she enjoys organizing content and finding patterns, she never met a spreadsheet she didn’t like.

About Krista. Krista Siniscarco is Associate Director, UX Strategy at BEAM Interactive. Krista’s focus on research and strategy, combined with her background in user experience design, allows her to bridge the strategy and design practices at BEAM. She has worked on brands such as American Greetings, Department of Defense, National Geographic Channel and Fidelity Investments. Before making the transition to an agency, Krista worked for several years in higher education as an educational technologist specializing in instructional design, visual design, and media literacy. She combines her background in teaching and learning with design research, design thinking, service design, and strategy to advocate for the user and design user-centric digital experiences.

3. Sex, Drugs, and Disease: Designing for Uncomfortable Topics (7:25-7:50)

By Jonathan Abbett | Twitter | LinkedIn

Not every product can have cheeky, casual content — especially in healthcare, when patients and families may be overwhelmed with cancer diagnoses, recovering from abuse, or afraid of stigma and discrimination. At ACT.md, our design team encountered this in a dramatic way: Massachusetts law requires that a patient's authorization for sharing health data include specific call-outs for (really) sensitive conditions, and our application's authorization agreement—shown front-and-center during user enrollment—had to comply. This show-and-tell talk will share the best practices and assumptions behind our patient authorization design, plus our experiences testing it with patients and families.

About Jonathan. Jonathan Abbett is Director of User Experience at ACT.md, a Boston healthcare startup with user experience as its foundation. He has spent his entire career in healthcare, designing and building software for patients, care providers, and researchers at Boston Children's Hospital, Massachusetts General Hospital, Harvard Medical School, and the Novartis Institutes for BioMedical Research. With a background in computer science, Jonathan is also passionate about strengthening the designer-developer relationship and encouraging UX designers to lead software teams.

4. Catalyst! (8:00 -9:00)

Physical Security 
We'd like to make things easy for Google Security. Everybody should update their meetup profile with their last name and a recent photograph. To do that, click My Profile > View Profile and you'll see the options.

Parking 
You may want to allow extra time to find a parking space, but street parking is available on the side streets. Pilgrim Parking, 350 Kendall Street has an $8 rate if you enter after 4pm. Here's a landmark of where to find us.

Not receiving emails? 
Some members have said they are not receiving our emails. You might have unsubscribed to our special announcements. To fix it: Click Settings > Email Updates > Choose UX Boston under "Updates about your groups" and check off "Announcement about a specific Meetup" and "Announcement to members about the group".

Why are you charging $1? 
It takes a good amount of effort and time to put on these events. The nominal $1 fee and checkout process serve to verify your attendance and provide a more accurate headcount — and ensure a much better networking experience! Your modest support does enable and encourage us to continue improving these events.

Sales and Recruiters 
We appreciate your interest in our events; however, in order to keep the focus on learning and having fun in a casual environment, we request that you not engage in marketing, sales, or recruitment business at our meetups. If you would like to attend or mingle with our members in a professional capacity to promote a product or recruit, please contact us directly about sponsorship opportunities through the Meetup site.

Looking for speakers! 
If you messaged your an abstract of your talk to us in the past and haven't received a response yet, please message it again. Your message may have been buried in layers of emails. Reminders are really helpful!

SEASONS — November 2015 to December 2015

A special exhibition hosted at the Dedham Community Theatre

580 High St, Dedham, Massachusetts 02026


Opening Reception: Thursday November 5th, 6pm to 8pm
Exhibition Dates: November 1, 2015 to December 31, 2015

In New England, there are four seasons: Summer, Fall, Winter and Spring. There is a season of giving. Andrew Wyeth explored seasons in his paintings with umbers, ochres and siennas. Ansel Adams used form and texture, as realized through light and shadow to create is black and white landscape photographs that explored seasonal change. “To every thing there is a season.”

results.description:
After seeing the very inspiring talk of George Church at the MIT Museum this week, we will address a very hot topic of synthetic biology for our next journal club: Gene drives. 

If you don’t know what they are, or if you want to know more about them, join us! You can find this open source paper at the following link:http://elifesciences.org/content/early/2014/07/15/eLife.03401

The agenda for the journal club:
• Short overview of the papers to understand the scope of the paper. So it is clear what is important and what is not.
• Go over the paper figure by figure. So everyone understand what exactly was done and how it was done.
• Free form discussion.

Previous reading of the paper is not required but much advised. It will help to do not get lost.

See you all soon!

The Boslab team

Location update:

The location changes to MIT Center for Biomedical Engineering, Room 216 (500 Technology Square Cambridge). It is a big building with rounded corners windows to the left from Technology Square. A couple of us will be waiting at the main entrance to let people in. Look for this face<a> http://www.meetup.com/BosLab/members/81819002/</a>;. If you are lost or got late call (256)[masked], someone will let you in.
results.name: Journal Club: RNA-guided gene drives for the alteration of wild populations

results.description:
CS 101 – Computer Concepts

Do you want to make the leap to Web Development or Programming but not sure where to start?

Do you want to gain a better understanding of how computers work?

CS101 provides a broad overview of common computer concepts and will give you the background you need to talk the talk. Join us and start filling in the gaps.

We’ll cover the following:


Class One:


     Hardware: Explanation and Evolution from 1960 to present

     What exactly is a computer?

     Architectures: Client Server, Cloud, CDN and Web Server

    Software: Front-end vs. back-end languages, Operating Systems

     Memory/Disk Storage: bits, bytes, megabytes, gigabytes…

Class Two:

     ASCII, Binary, Decimal and Hex

    Color theory

     How to style your code, comments

     Data Types: variables, strings, integers, doubles, arrays, linked list

     Loops and logic: if/then/else, while loops

Class Three:

     Loops and logic: if/then/else, while loops, Continued

     What is a function, parameters

     Global vs. Local Variables

     Tools of the Trade: git, sublime, filezilla, Chrome Developer Tools


This is a 3 part class to be held on the following Thursdays:

November 5th, 12th and 19th, 6:30-8:30pm

Cost: $75

Prerequisite: None.


Why smartyGirl? We keep our classes small by limiting each class to 12 students. This allows us to both better meet the diverse technical background of each student and to get to know one another in class. We encourage older women to join in the fun.

About the Instructor: Sara has been creating, programming and teaching for many years. She has a Masters in Computer Science and loves teaching technology to women and creating amazing websites.
results.name: CS101 - Computer Concepts

Come work on Python projects, get programming help, help others, and hang out. Sponsored by Mitra Capital.

Python project nights are unstructured chances for Python developers to work together, mentor each other, connect socially, teach, learn, or do whatever else it is Python developers want to do together.

Our project nights are great ways to build the Python community, by allowing them to meet and interact in whatever way they find most beneficial.

Food: Pizza will be provided.

Things to bring: a wireless-enabled laptop and power cord.

Need some project ideas? How about:

Learning Python

• The official Python tutorial

• How to Think Like a Computer Scientist: Learning with Python

• An introduction to Python through writing games

• Learn Python the Hard Way

Projects and competitions

• Puzzles!

• Contribute to an open-source project that uses Python. Developers from OpenHatch, Twisted, and other projects are often here. If you contribute to an open source project that uses Python and want to help new contributors, let us know in a comment!

• Want to learn a Python web framework? Check out the Django tutorial.
results.name: Boston Python November Project Night

results.description:
Hello,

Thank you for visiting this page. Whether you're new to Massachusetts, new to Toastmasters or looking for a different club, this is the place to be. We meet every FIRST & THIRD Thursdays of every month, twice a month.

This is a very friendly supportive, encouraging environment. members come come a variety of cultures and academic & professional background. 

Minutemen Toastmasters Club is a great place to learn to speak in front of the audience, accept constructive feedback, manage your time and network with a diverse culture, that is committed to each other's success.

If you are new, you can attend the club three times to assess if it meets your needs. On the third meeting we suggest you join the club as a member. You are also free to visit other clubs to satisfy your personal needs. 


Please RSVP for all the future meetings!!


Thank you,

~VJ / VP Membership

results.description:
Itadaki downstairs bar (Boston, Newbury St. between Gloucester and Fairfield) 7 pm to 10 pm

Join me at this izakaya style venue for a pleasant evening of drinks, food and chats. Whether you're learning Japanese or English, buy a drink, join the table, and practice your new language in a friendly and relaxed environment. If you're a beginner or just interested in culture, you'll fit in fine! Don't miss out on this opportunity to learn and practice over a few drinks. Can't make it on time? Need to leave early? Not a problem. Just stop by if you can!

If you are >21 and plan to drink, please bring a MA state issued ID or passport. Other state IDs may not be accepted. Please order at the bar and take care of your own tab.

Transportation: I highly recommend using public transportation. Not only is driving while intoxicated dangerous, but there may not be any parking available in the area. A lot of the parking on Newbury St  is Residential Only in the evenings, and many of the signs indicating this are very well hidden. If you insist on parking in the area, be aware that meter maids love handing out parking tickets around here. Best methods for public transportation are the green line subway or bus #1 to the Hynes stop.

I have made an arrangements with the Itadaki staff for a simpler ordering method. Last time was very chaotic and stressful for the bartender, so lets do our best to not confuse the bartender. :)

Ordering at Itadaki

1) Order your first drink at the bar. If it's alcoholic, your ID will be checked at this time. You will also be  given a guest number to use the rest of the night.

2) If you're at a table, the bartender will try to make several rounds throughout the night to take additional orders. Keep using your guest number and please feel free to order more food and drinks.

3) Keep in mind we're a pretty large group so don't be offended or annoyed with the bartender if he doesn't get to you right away. If you have an urgent order, go request it at the bar.

4) Please take care of your tab and don't forget to tip*. The management and staff are doing a lot to make this all possible.

*Note: If the group is large, an 18% tip may already be included.

See you there!
~Lindsay
results.how_to_find_us: Go to the downstairs bar and look for the sign!

results.description:
Though we might wish we could, we can't always think of everything ourselves. Join Danny and other writers for a chance to engage your writing with a community and get the kind of new, original feedback that gets the writing juices flowing. Before every meeting we'll each submit a short story, section of a novel or other work to be reviewed (up to 10-12 double spaced pages or[masked] words*). Come prepared to give written and verbal feedback on others' work as well as receive feedback on your own. Open to all, but limited to 5 each session (plus organizers) on a first come first serve basis.

Please RSVP and be prepared to submit your work about a week before we meet to give everyone a chance to read. The latest time to RSVP is 3 days prior.

Submissions are hosted on a shared Box.com folder, which requires an email address to access.  If this is your first time joining, let Danny know your preferred email address and he will invite you.

Monthly
Cost is $15

Led by Danny Shain

Danny graduated from Union College with a degree in English, and has spent years working as a copy-editor, freelance writer and blogger.  A follower of technology trends whose reading interests range from the fantastical to the contemporary to the philosophical, Danny is excited to help people refine their writing, express themselves, and build a writing community through this workshop.

*Note: If you'd like to include slightly more than 10-12 pages to provide some context (ie: your chapter ends 1-2 pages later) that's ok, but please indicate which pages you'd like critiqued. Pages beyond that should be submitted as an optional read.
results.how_to_find_us: Ask the concierge when you come in and you will be directed to the conference room.

results.description:
Coal Mine is a tool for monitoring recurring tasks and alerting when they fail to report on time.

It's an OSS, Python 3 implementation of services like Dead Man's Snitch, Cronitor.io, and Sheriff. Come learn about Coal Mine, why you need it, and how to use it.

If you want to play with Coal Mine prior to the meetup, you can install it from PyPI or access the source code in Github. Also, there's a Vagrantfile you can use to easily launch a VM running the server. You can also use this Vagrantfile to follow along with the demo at the meetup.

results.name: Topic: OSS Project - Coal Mine

results.description:
Are you interested in getting more involved in sexual freedom activism? Join Nicole Mazzeo of Pleasure Pie (pleasurepie.org) for a discussion on activism and creating sexual freedom based communities.

This workshop is an interactive guide to figuring out how you can use your passion for sexual freedom to create real change. We'll talk about how you can find ways to help create a more sexually accepting culture that reflect your skills and interests, whether they include writing, researching, starting conversations, making art, nurturing the people around you, or anything else you might be good at!

Nicole is making a new zine just for this event! It's called The Sexual Freedom Activism Field Guide, and everyone who comes to this workshop will get a free copy!

This is for people of all genders.

Nicole is really psyched and honored to be presenting at Good Vibrations. Please come out and show your support! Tickets are $20 in advance, $25 at the door. Buy tickets here: http://www.brownpapertickets.com/event/2304531

When attending or registering please let Nicole know you heard about the event from the Pleasure Without Borders Meetup.


Looking forward to seeing you there! :)

results.description:
Ongoing class in Medieval and Renaissance Longsword in the tradition of Johannes Lichtenauer.


The Longsword is the iconic fantasy Knight's sword - a two-handed, straight blade with a cross guard. The weapon may seem to be simple at first but is in reality a weapon of finesse and skill.


The class covers all the basics of footwork, attacks and defenses. Drills are developed from simple to complex; from rigidly choreographed to open-ended. Timing, distance and judgement are developed.


All classes begin with a Strength & Conditioning program designed to physically prepare one for fighting with the sword. Elements develop agility, core stability and power.

(Technical Support: <a>[masked]</a>)


The Inner Engineering online program includes guided meditations, powerful breathing techniques, and deeply engaging discourses about the nature of the mind and practical wisdom to manage life’s situations.

Inner Engineering is a combination of methods derived from the ancient science of yoga that addresses every aspect of human well-being — from your body, mind and emotions to the essential life energy within.

This 1 hour introduction to Inner Engineering explains the fundamental approach of the program in a live setting that offers you the opportunity to ask a trained Isha teacher questions about the program and practices available.

“Inner Engineering is neither a religion, nor a philosophy or dogma; It is a technology for wellbeing. One does not have to believe or disbelieve, you just have to learn to use it. Technology will produce results irrespective of who you are.” – Sadhguru

results.description:
November 5, 6 - Taurids Meteor Shower. The Taurids is a long-running minor meteor shower producing only about 5-10 meteors per hour. It is unusual in that it consists of two separate streams. The first is produced by dust grains left behind by Asteroid 2004 TG10. The second stream is produced by debris left behind by Comet 2P Encke. The shower runs annually from September 7 to December 10. It peaks this year on the the night of November 5. The second quarter moon will block out all but the brightest meteors this year. If you are patient, you may still be able to catch a few good ones. Best viewing will be just after midnight from a dark location far away from city lights. Meteors will radiate from the constellation Taurus, but can appear anywhere in the sky.

Source(s):
http://www.seasky.org/astronomy/astronomy-calendar-current.html
results.name: Taurids Meteor Shower

results.description:
November 6, 2015

Get a Retail Trends Update at the North Shore Business Forum’s Meeting on Friday, November 6, 2015.</a>

Featured Speaker: Mark Whiting, Mall Manager, Northshore Mall – “Retail Trends and Community Engagement”

The North Shore Business Forum (NSBF) meets on Friday, November 6, 2015 at Acapulcos, 900 Cummings Center, Beverly, MA. Get an update on general retail trends and the importance of community engagement for large and small businesses on the North Shore from speaker Mark Whiting, Mall Manager of Northshore Mall, a Simon property in Peabody, MA. Registration begins at 7:15 AM, the meeting runs from 7:30 to 8:30. Admission is $10 at the door, and includes a buffet breakfast. Visit <a href="http://www.nsbforum.org/">www.nsbforum.org for more information. 

With the holiday season approaching, local business owners need to get up to speed on expected retail trends and events. Speaker Mark Whiting will offer his perspective, and also highlight the ways North Shore businesses can engage with the community. One example is the Simon Youth Peabody Learning Academy at Northshore Mall, which supports students who were once at risk of dropping out of high school and which is recognized as one of the most successful non-traditional high school programs on the North Shore.

About the Speaker: Mark Whiting began his career at Northshore Mall in 1997, where he is currently the Mall Manager. Prior to joining Northshore Mall, one of Simon Property Group’s premiere properties, he held executive roles at both Filene’s and Macy’s. He has also helped spearhead the Simon Youth Peabody Learning Academy at Northshore Mall, which is one of 22 Simon Youth Foundation (SYF) Academies nationwide that help at-risk students stay in school and graduate. SYF maintains a 90 percent cumulative graduation rate across all academies, including the one in Peabody. Mark graduated from Syracuse University in 1981 and resides in Stratham, NH with his wife, Ginny, and son, Ryan. For more information, contact Mark at [masked] or visit http://www.shopnorthshoremall.com.

The North Shore Business Forum, Inc. (NSBF) is a group of small business owners from Boston’s North Shore who meet on the first and third Friday of each month for informal lectures given by business owners on a wide variety of topics. Members give a 30-second introduction of their business at each meeting. All business owners are welcome: future, past, profitable, experienced or beginning. Meetings are from 7:30 to 8:30 a.m. (registration starts at 7:15) at Acapulcos, 900 Cummings Center, Beverly, MA. The $10.00 admission fee includes a breakfast buffet. No pre-registration necessary.
results.name: Learn the Basics of Retail Marketing

group.name: North Shore Business Forum - Business Networking at Acapulco

What happens when you explore beyond what is commonly thought possible? Do you dare to push beyond what’s been done before, to break out of your comfort zone, and challenge your beliefs? Come experience the phenomenon of TED TALKS right here in New Bedford! The Z and TEDx New Bedford come together to transform the theater into a day-long happening filled with inspiring speakers, TED TALK videos, and places to discuss ideas with fellow Tedx goers – like the on-site Community Conversation Café, complete with local restaurant and food truck dining options. TEDx New Bedford:uNBound will showcasefeatured speakers who will introduce us to a world where ideas are put into action to radically transform companies, communities, people, and the way we live. You’re invited to connect with your community,gather inspiration, and cultivate new ideas through TED Talks video, live speakers and discussions. Come to all or any portion of the event.

results.description:
NUTSHELL - every week day, 12:15ish until 1:45ish, Cumnock Turf Fields at Harvard Stadium, games of 4v4 up to 10v10 or larger depending on who shows, bring a white shirt and a dark/colored shirt (but not a gray one), almost never canceled, read below for more details before asking questions that are answered here, and read the comments for today's meetup to see if there is anything important about today.

http://goo.gl/I0tPQQ

GETTING THERE BY PUBLIC TRANSPORT - Harvard Square is the closest T stop (red line).  Check Google Maps or other to find fastest way there from wherever you are.

GETTING THERE BY RIDE SHARE - a lot of players in this meetup come by car and are nice enough to offer rides to others. Best hope of getting a ride is leaving a comment here asking if anybody is driving and willing to pick you up.

PARKING - you must park at one of the metered spots if you park on Harvard property near the stadium.  They will patrol for cars parked illegally.

COST - free while we play outdoors.

ATTIRE - Bring a *white* shirt and a dark/vivid color shirt so we can easily divide into teams.  DO NOT BRING A GRAY SHIRT- you will annoy a lot of people if you do. Turf shoes or cleats recommended, and sneakers are fine.  Shin-guards optional- most people don't wear them. Bring a ball if you have one.

RSVP and CANCELING - the sooner you RSVP, the better.  That said, most people don't RSVP until around 10:30am the day of the meetup, so we make the call around 11:15am the day of the meetup about whether a game needs to be canceled.  Check here right before heading over.

ETIQUETTE - we have A LOT of players in this meetup and play every (week)day. Each day is a different mix of people, skill levels, and attitudes.  Most people playing do this for fun and/or exercise in the middle of the day.  Please respect this by at least following these unspoken rules that we have:

1) You may not hurt anybody- especially yourself. All of us just want to safely return to the office/class afterward.

2) Do not yell at, criticize, or offer unsolicited "tips" to other players unless they ask for your opinion. It ruins an otherwise fun, all-skill-levels game. If you do this often, you may be asked to find another meetup.

3) Be the first to get the ball if it goes out of bounds. Especially if you kicked it last or are the closest one to the ball.

4) Fighting is prohibited. We've never come close to having a problem with this, but better stated aloud. If it gets physical, we may call the police as it becomes a felony/legal matter.

WHAT ELSE - All skill levels welcome- it's a big mix. While these are general guidelines, always read the comments section for the latest updates for today's meetup.
results.name: Friday Lunchtime Soccer (OUTDOOR)

results.description:
MFA First Friday Social Art Evening Museum of Fine Arts (West Wing Information room),Address: 465 Huntington Ave, Boston, MA 02115 tel[masked]


<------

Save wait time in line by entering the rear (Fenway )entrance of the MFA since the front gets busy.

<---------

ORGANIZER: Jimmy he will have signs out on the back tables at the MFA Ruth and Carl J. Shapiro Family Courtyard.

TARGET AUDIENCE: All Members of ALL AGES that like Art and a relaxed social atmosphere!

Admission: $25 per person -- Free for MFA Members. ...If you are an MFA members please try to arrange through comments to help get other members of our group in as your guest for free. You can also try to get a discount pass at your local library get you in for free or $10 a Person. Hey we all need to save a few bucks for drink later right?

Drop off your coats, buy your entry tickets and meet us all at the SHARF VISITOR CENTER at 5:45PM. After that try to find us in the Ruth and Carl J. Shapiro Family Courtyard its where the party is at. and it the big tall room with the huge green glass Chihuly art piece is in. Stay as long as you want. MFA First Fridays ends at 9PM the Museum closed at 9:45PM.

MFA First Fridays is on the first Friday of each month from 6:00–9:30 pm. Join us for fine art, music, cash bars featuring signature cocktails, and delicious tapas available for purchase. Open to visitors 21+. Valid ID with proof of age required for entry.

Accepted forms of identification for First Friday entrance include:
Massachusetts Drivers License
Massachusetts Liquor ID
Massachusetts ID issued by the Massachusetts Registry of Motor Vehicles
Drivers License from any US state
Valid Passport (photocopies are not accepted)
Federal Identification (e.g. Military ID)

We can mix and mingle with fellow art lovers,  enjoy the art,  the music and sip on our lovely drinks. hen we can break off and look at some more art since the rest of the museum is open!

Hope you can make it out this fine Friday Evening out for some Art Culture and great conversations.

======================================================

Notes for Parking for the MFA: It will be busy and lots tend to fill up fast so try to get there early! Taking the T is your best bet!

Self Parking Options: Visitors to the MFA have three self-parking options: the Huntington Lot, the Fenway Lot, and the Museum Road Garage, all of which have entrances on Museum Road. The Huntington lot offers closer parking to the Huntington Avenue Entrance and the Fenway parking lot is more accessible to the State Street Corporation Fenway Entrance. MFA lost Park costs $$$ over $20 so be prepared.

Subway Take the Green Line E train to the Museum of Fine Arts stop, or the Orange Line train to the Ruggles stop.
results.how_to_find_us: Drop off your coats, buy your entry tickets and meet us all at the SHARF VISITOR CENTER at 5:45PM.
results.name: MFA First Friday Social Art Evening

results.description:
Beth will be offering another Fun Financial Workshop for those of you who were unable to attend the last one. 

We all learned so much (please read the posts from October 9th).

Learn 5 Essential Planning Strategies for Financial Freedom

Everyone has different financial objectives. Whether it is to save for a secure comfortable retirement, pay for your child’s college education, buy a house, take a vacation, make sure your bills are paid on time, or get out of debt, this workshop will help you accomplish your goals.  

Learn strategies and basic principles that will help you achieve your financial goals. Financial literacy will improve your money management skills. If you would like to: 

• Learn the fundamentals of investing

• Identify challenges that are blocking opportunities to a higher net worth

• Increase your awareness on spending & how to save money

• Learn the Do’s & Don’ts to a secure financial future

• Get your questions answered & share what empowers you to get motivated

Beth Hughes has been an Independent Financial Planner for 10 years. Prior to working in finance she was an RN for 18 years. Her passion for educating people on financial literacy is evident in all her workshops. The goal is for everyone to experience a fun, educational, interactive evening.

Beverages & light food offered.

There has been quite a response for this workshop which shows that this is something the you ladies would like to learn about. So, we will be planning a 2nd workshop for those of you who do not make it into this one.  2nd date will be announced  one week prior to October 9th.

We will congregate and get some tables to the left near the big cube with the poster, which has the stairs and the elevator behind it.

Try not to be late, as it fills up quickly and then they stop letting people in. I am BIll, 6'4".

I will usually email my phone # before the event to attendees so if you miss us in the foyer you can call or text (preferred) if you can't find us when/if you get in.   Look at everyone's pictures so we know who is going.  I will try to bring a copy of the pictures and will keep an eye out to say hi & introduce people.

BE SURE TO GET THERE EARLY, AS THE PLACE FILLS UP AND THEY TURN PEOPLE AWAY.  You need a license or Mass ID to enter.

Please change your RSVP if you can not make it.

We can go out after for food or drinks at a convenient location, such as a restaurant on Huntington Ave.

results.description:
Red Larch is a little town on the Long Road, a few days' travel north of Waterdeep and south of Yartar. It's a waystation for caravans coming to or from the cities of the North, with only one inn, the Swinging Sword.  An important delegation from the city of Mirabar disappeared in the nearby Sumber Hills. The whole town is also abuzz with news and rumors of fierce raiders, roaming monsters, suspicious strangers, and unseasonable weather.  The five factions know about the overdue delegation and are concerned enough to send agents to investigate.  Characters affiliated with these factions are contacted and asked to help out. Tell each player in private why his or her faction is concerned about the missing delegation.

 The party completed a task for Constable Harburk regarding a bandit lair south of town.  The party easily handled the attack by the four bandits & a captured a black bear particularly thanks to high stealth / perception rolls on their part and poor ones by the DM.

 The party also followed up on rumor regarding a ghost at the tomb in the graveyard outside of town.  They narrowly survived the side trip as the encounter with a half orc & goblin duo who preyed on travelers heading to the graveyard combined with the specter guarding the tomb nearly claimed one of the party members. The party has collected several rumors in talking with the patrons in the inn & at one of the shops.  The decision ahead of them is which rumor to follow next and where will it lead them …….

This is a biweekly D&D 5e group.  The group is usually full and meets at a private residence, but as always if you are interested in a similar group in the future, please post a comment or message me through the Meetup site (click my name, then click the speech bubble labelled "Message" on my profile page). 


There should be room for *one* waitlist slot to join this group.
results.name: Temple of Elemental Evil (Episode 2)

group.name: The Boston Dungeons & Dragons Meetup Group

results.description:
For more than 20 years the Boston Beanstalks have gathered on the first Friday night of the month at the Riverbend Lounge (formerly the Windjammer) at the Newton Marriott. This is the biggest regularly scheduled event on our calendar. It's not uncommon to see 40 or more tall people here, and you won't be the only new or prospective member! This is the place to start your social calendar planning, arrange carpooling for various events, and find out what's going on with all your Tall friends.

If there's enough interest, we'll head into the restaurant around 8:00 PM to continue the conversation and get something to eat.

Location: Marriott Hotel, 2345 Commonwealth Avenue (Rt. 30) in Newton
Time: 6-8 PM, usually dinner afterwards to 10pm
Cost: optional drinks
Directions: Rt. 128 to exit 24 (Rt. 30). At the end of the ramp, go right. The Marriott is just ahead on your left.

More on the Newton Marriott
results.name: The Boston Beanstalks Tall Club Monthly Meetup
