results.description:
The Museum of Fine Arts is open from 6PM to 9:30PM on first Fridays. The entire museum is open. In the Shapiro Courtyard (the indoor courtyard with the Chihuly green glass Christmas Tree and the restaurant) the MFA sets up a cash bar and a DJ. From 6PM its mostly 40s to 60s, to talk. After about 7PM the volume of the music goes up, the 25-35 year olds arrive, and the event shifts from talk to dancing (and it gets too loud for me, so I go look at art). The place often fills up a bit after 7, so don’t be later than that.

http://www.mfa.org/programs/special-event/mfa-first-fridays

Museum admission and event ticketing. The event is free with museum admission, either for members or general admission ($25, $23 for seniors), either at the door or online at http://www.mfa.org/visit. Many local libraries sell discounted tickets, for example two tickets for $10. Also, many employers may have discounted or even free tickets for their employees, check your human resources department.

First Friday is separately ticketed (at no additional charge), even if you are a member or preticketed.  You need to get a separate ticket, either through the admission line at the door, or a separate desk at the Fenway end of the Sharf Visitor Center.  The line is tolerable at 6:00PM, and can be way way bad at 6:10.

If people have dual memberships they can get others in for free. As we gather at the front lobby, we can figure out any ticket sharing arrangements.

Open to visitors 21+. Valid ID with proof of age required for entry.

It's not complicated.  Just show up and find one or another of the Meetup groups.  Someone will point you to the right lines to stand in, and maybe share a ticket.


Transportation. Public transportation strongly recommended, parking is a pain. The Green E line stops right in front of the museum. Also there are several buses that also stop in front of the museum. Directions by every transportation mode at http://www.mfa.org/visit/getting-here, www.mbta.com .  There are three parking structures on Museum Road, $20 and up.


Meeting up with others—how to find us. The Fine Culture in Boston and Culture Vultures groups meet in the Huntington Avenue main entrance lobby at 6PM near the statue of Orpheus and Cerberus (3 headed dog).  Other meetup groups meet at the Fenway door. Then we will head in at 6:10.

If you arrive later, as you enter the courtyard, look to your left, and meet us at the tables near the elevator station with the poster of the current show.

Please change your RSVP if you can not make it.

After. The event closes at 9:30.  We can go out after for food or drinks at a convenient location, such as a restaurant on Huntington Ave.
results.name: MFA First Friday—Conversation, Art, Music, Dancing

group.name: Fine Culture in Boston (and International Travel)

results.description:
Dear Boston Culture Lovers,

Join us at the MFA First Friday in December.

You will be able to enjoy fine art, music, cash bars featuring signature cocktails, and delicious tapas available for purchase.

Open to visitors 21+. Valid ID with proof of age required for entry.

Tickets

For Members, you may order free tickets for this event on the MFA web site.

For non-members, you  may purchase your tickets that include general Museum admission in person on the day of the event on a  first come, first served basis, or in advance, online.

For discounted/free tickets. The cost of general admission is $25 ($23 for seniors).  However, you may be able to get a discounted ticket at your local library.

Your local library most likely has discounted passes available.  Typically the discount is two tickets at $10 per admission.  Also, many employers may have discounted or even free tickets for their employees. You may want to check your human resources department if such discounted/free tickets exist for you.

The MFA website strongly recommends that you purchase your tickets in advance due to the risk of  this event selling out.  I heard that this event rarely sells out, however it sometimes happens in the summer months.  I just wanted to give you fair warning. 

The plan is to meet at 6pm in lounge/couch area of the Sharf Visitor Center on the first floor.  Otherwise, at 6 :15 pm sharp, we walk a few steps away into the main social event at the Shapiro Courtyard. 

Since this event will be a somewhat crowded and roaming , it will be very difficult for latecomers to connect with the group. If you are late, I can not guarantee that you will recognize me or fellow members or we  to be able  recognize you from the crowds.  Once the event starts, I put away my smartphone and concentrate on enjoying the event with fellow group members.  Please plan ahead and allow a little extra travel time to this event. Typically, there are a lot Meetup groups present.  There are usually Meetup signs posted at the tables near the entrance to the courtyard.  If you are late, don't be shy and introduce yourself.  A lot of attendees are regulars and will most likely point you other members of the group. 

If you need to familiarize yourself to this location, here is a link to the floor plan: http://mfas3.s3.amazonaws.com/Map_Sept2014_level1.pdf

I strongly recommend that you  take public transportation, the Green E line stops right in front of the museum. Also there are several buses that also stop in front of the museum. Check out these links for more information on getting to the museum: http://www.mfa.org/visit/getting-here, www.mbta.com .

Please only reserve "YES" if you are definitely attending and plan to meet members of the group.  If you reserve "YES" and have a change of plans, please update the attendance reservation.

I look forward to enjoying this event with the group.

Joana

http://mfas3.s3.amazonaws.com/styles/grid-3_thumbnail_retina/s3/mfa-summer-fridays-landing-page_0.jpg?itok=i2jETF4C

results.description:
BYOB Faith and Film
6:30 doors open
6:45 Screening
8:45 Discussion

This month's film was nominated for five Academy Awards among many (2000).

In an unusual French chocolate shop, a lovely proprietor creates mouth-watering confections, shakes up the rigid morality of the community and eventually inspires locals to abandon themselves to temptation and happiness.

Here's what people said about the film:

"The most tempting of all sweets becomes the key weapon in a battle of sensual pleasure versus disciplined self-denial in this comedy."

"A mythic fable about tolerance and love with the bitter-sweet flavor of a candy that's not entirely fresh but still digestible."

"Any movie built on the premise that chocolate can cure mental illness, restore marital passion, unite feuding relatives, assuage anger, defeat oppression, inspire art and get you a date with Johnny Depp is all right in my book."

Sanctuary’s Faith and Film happens every month – a BYOB. Bring your own beer, wine or soda and experience the places where Pop culture meets our faith. We will watch a current film followed by a discussion about themes of morality, faith, and humanity led by local theologians and community leaders.

*Sanctuary’s film licensing agreement does not allow us to advertise the film title. Please be in touch or join our mailing list to receive details about each month’s film.

High Definition/Large Screen-ing, comfortable seating,light snacks and discussion led by Anastasia Kidd and Chad Kidd;

A Free Will Offering will be collected.

Call<a>[masked]</a> or email <a>[masked]</a> to find out the film title and to get on our mailing list for details about our monthly Faith and Film events as well as our other Arts and Inspiration programs (music, art gallery, and the spoken word).


*Note: Our film licensing agreement does not allow us to publicly market the name of the film.

Also: see the events page at sanctuaryucc.org

results.description:
Let's connect with people that are building cooperative platforms.

On November 13 and 14, Agaric members will be going to the New School in New York City, where they are hosting a coming-out party for the cooperative Internet, built of platforms owned and governed by the people who rely on them. The program will include discussion sessions, screenings, monologues, legal hacks, workshops, and dialogues, as well as a showcase of projects, both conceptual and actual. We’ll learn from coders and worker cooperatives, scholars and designers. Together, we’ll put their lessons to work as we work toward usable apps and structural economic change. This is your chance to get on the ground floor of the next Internet, and to help make it a reality.

http://platformcoop.net Registration is free, and tickets are still available.

Micky will be interviewed twice at the event - Once by the event hosts Trebor Scholz and Nathan Schneider. For this interview, the question to all speakers is the same: “What is your contribution to Platform Cooperativism?

The second interview is with the Laura Flanders Show and will feature Micky and Janelle Orsi. The topic will be laws and cooperatives that use free software.

Do you have any questions about the laws that affect cooperatives and make it harder for them to form, operate and offer benefits?
It looks to be a great opportunity to connect with some potential allies, and come upon some well-thought-out ideas. Please, take a look at the participants list and see if there is anyone interesting you would like to connect with:

http://platformcoop.net/participants

There are some wild projects and goings-on: this is not your average conference! If you are going, we could discuss how we might work together to cover more ground at the conference. If you cannot attend, but would like us to bring along certain ideas, or raise certain questions, we'll do our best to make those connections.


Platform Cooperativism is convened by Trebor Scholz (The New School) and Nathan Schneider (University of Colorado Boulder).

Anyone interested in carpooling  - contact us.

Further reading:

By Trebor Scholz:
Platform "Cooperativism vs. the Sharing Economy” (December 5, 2014)  http://tinyurl.com/oj8rna2
”Think Outside the Boss,” Public Seminar (April 5, 2015) http://www.publicseminar.org/2015/04/think-outside-the-boss/#.VUoVZEuhIds

By Nathan Schneider
“Owning Is the New Sharing,” Shareable (December 21, 2014) http://www.shareable.net/blog/owning-is-the-new-sharing

We have setup a way for you to join our dialog, even if you cannot attend the event.  Add to the list of projects and speakers you would like to see and share notes on, before, during or after the conference :


http://piratepad.net/platformcoop

results.description:
FREE FREE FREE FREE FREE FREE FREE FREE FREE FREE FREE FREE

Co-Presented with The Word Boston
Q&A with Walter Mosley and Donna Latson Gittens

following the screening Always Outnumbered, Always Outgunned

See Walter Mosley’s work translated from gripping novel to a film starring Laurence Fishburne. Socrates Fortlow has done his time: twenty-seven years for murder and rape, acts forged by his huge, rock-breaking hands. Now, he has come home to a new kind of prison: two battered rooms in an abandoned building in Watts. Working for the Bounty supermarket, and moving perilously close to invisibility, it is Socrates who throws a lifeline to a drowning man: young Darryl, whose shaky path is already bloodstained and fearsome. In a place of violence and hopelessness, Socrates offers up his own battle-scarred wisdom that can turn the world around. 

**This event is currently sold out but tickets may become available. Please check back in the event that tickets are returned. There will also be a waitlist for unclaimed tickets at the Box Office one hour prior to the event.** .


DATE: Friday November 6th 7 PM

LOCATION: Paramount Center Bright Family Screening Room

Register at this link https://artsemerson.org/Online/seatSelect.asp?BOset::WSmap::seatmap::performance_ids=5D02A5F5-A091-4C03-9371-497E6E8BDAF1

ArtsEmerson and the Future Boston Alliance Present:

WALTER MOSLEY: THE OBSESSIVE RESIDENCY Fresh Sound Master Artist in Residence Launching his memoir, The Graphomaniac’s Primer
OCT 30 – NOV 8, 2015


One of the most versatile and admired artists in America today, Walter Mosley is a critically acclaimed novelist, playwright, screenwriter and visual artist. He is author to more than 43 critically acclaimed books, including the major bestselling mystery series featuring Easy Rawlins. His work has been translated into 23 languages and includes literary fiction, science fiction, political monographs, and a young adult novel. His short fiction has been widely published, and his nonfiction has appeared in The New York Times Magazine and The Nation, among other publications. He is the winner of numerous awards, including an O. Henry Award, a Grammy and PEN America’s Lifetime Achievement Award. 

In celebration of his new autobiography, The Graphomaniac’s Primer, ArtsEmerson and the Future Boston Alliance invite you to The Obsessive Residency, featuring an array of Walter Mosley’s expansive portfolio of fiction, plays, and visual art. Don’t miss this rare opportunity to explore and celebrate the mind of an artist constantly in creation and heralded as “one of the most humane, insightful, powerful sylists working today in any genre” (The Austin Chronicle).

**Some of the Walter Mosley Residency events are appearing as SOLD OUT. However, tickets may become available! Tickets are frequently returned or exchanged for other performances, so check back later.  Additionally, on the day of a given performance, a waitlist will be started at the Emerson/Paramount Center one hour prior to each curtain and any available tickets will be released for sale beginning a fifteen minutes prior to curtain to the people on the wait list. You must be in person at the Box Office to be placed on the waitlist and when your name is called.**

results.description:
RELEASING FEAR
Presented by, Andrea Kukulka Healing Medium.

What could you accomplish if your fears did not exist?

I have found that our fears are not always what we believe them to be. Some fears are right there on the surface just waiting for us to acknowledge them while others are rooted very deeply. As you read this you're examining what you believe are your fears. While you're doing this you may even be keeping the deepest ones very comfortably buried.  Let's expose them and get rid of them!

In this workshop we'll use meditation to tap into that place where our fears live. Together we'll process them and throw them out. 

Just imagine how much more you can do without fear holding you back!

*$45 at the door, cash or check*
*Click HERE to pay with a credit card on line.*

Boston Frisbee is going back to it's roots tonight and playing at the Boston Common at 7pm. This is both a change in location and time from our regular Meetups so please spread the word. An important note: bring SNEAKERS, NOT CLEATS TONIGHT. Cleats are not allowed on the Common. It helps keep the fields beautiful. Prepare for an awesome, spirited game lit by glow sticks, you're sparkly smiles, and hopefully ambient light from the baseball fields!!

Here's the game plan:

7:00 - Toss the disc around, meet folks, be merry

7:10 - Overview of the rules, safety, etc - then divide into teams

7:20 - Play!!!!!!

9:00 - Conclude the meetup and begin socializing.

Here's what we humbly ask of you (works great as a checklist):

Dress for the weather

Bring a white and a dark-colored t-shirt. Grey is evil. If you wear grey you may be asked to wear a light or dark "pinnie of shame."

Arrive on time to be guaranteed a spot in a game

RSVP is recommended so you can be notified if the game is canceled

Bring WATER!

If you are a regular, please consider bringing a buck for the Frisbee Fund

As usual, we will supply the frisbees, cones, first aid supplies (hopefully will never be used) and our pretty smiles. As we periodically mention, all these supplies are paid out-of-pocket by your loving Frisbee organizers and everyone has been so generous with their donations to-date. Thank you and let's keep the dream alive!

PROGRAM by:  Izzy Briggs  ---  "Stories Told from the Paint-booth"

Short presentation on what it takes to paint an aircraft. We will discuss paint types, surface prep, stripping, sanding, repairing, appropriate applications, pin striping, weight considerations, paint-booth construction, post painting polishing and buffing,  bugs, humidity, fixing runs, orange peel, air pressure, line driers, fisheye, pinholes, bondo vs epoxy, safety, safety and Safety and space containment.

Penny comment:  Even if you don't have an aircraft to paint soon, this should be an interesting and useful presentation if you have ANY painting project in your future - aircraft or automotive ...  It's also an opportunity to come meet Izzy, your future President.

results.description:
<We will sing inspiring songs, come together in community, and let the sound in each of us be heard.If you're inspired by music, by community, by authentic expression... you'll want to join us!>

                                                           Design by Sarah May Gubkin


Let your heart sing!
Do you love to sing, but…?
Do you yearn to step into fuller expression? To be heard? To hear yourself? In a circle tradition in sacred space, and with love and acceptance, we will weave song and meditation to inspire us to gently embrace and allow our voices to express from within. It doesn’t matter how you sound, because this is about:
• the energy that flows (and doesn’t care if we’re in tune),
• opening a door to your heart and giving it wings to express,
• bringing the wisdom of many song traditions into our daily lives, and
• the power of supportive community.
In a SpiritSong circle, we learn to listen deeply and open to the beautiful spaces within, and we are heard without judgment. We cultivate authentic expression. We share in the healing joy of sound!

Our facilitator for this Evening

Carolyn Sprague, is a certified SpiritSong Facilitator.  Trained by SpiritSong originator, Shawna Carol, Carolyn has a passion for song, for coming together in sacred gatherings, for uniting our voices. She listens deeply and leads gently, making even the most reluctant voices feel welcome, often using call and response techniques that make it easy to chime right in.

$$$ Your Heartfelt Donation makes more Inspiring Life events possible. $$$
                                                             Thank you!

You are warmly invited to join us at our monthly drop-in Inspiring Life: SpiritSong evening,  in Stow, MA.



I participated in a women's song circle years ago. It really inspired me, to have all those voices sounding as one, voicing the words of inspired musicians. I have yearned to create a local song circle ever since that time. Since my musical abilities are not aligned with leading a song circle, I just kept hoping someone would come along to lead. Getting to know Carolyn over time I became aware of her extraordinary qualities as a song leader. Eventually, one day, I asked, would you like to lead a song circle? I'll organize. We can hold it here. And, voila... we set up our first SpiritSong Circle here in Stow. We started slow, just trusted loved ones, and now we're ready to offer this wonderful experience to a wider audience! hooray! - MariePatrice

Does this event inspire you?  If you're inspired by Personal growth, Transformation, Healing, Awakening, Spirituality, Community, Nature and Ecology you'll want to check out our other
                                              INSPIRING LIFE events
                                      www.tinyURL.com/InspiringLife contact

or look for our events right here on the
Personal Growth Network.

It was an amazing experience .. It was nice to feel free from the world and it's problems .. It's was so relaxing, can't wait to drum again ..thanks!

Justin 6/14

Was an awesome experience, I love hand drumming but really the main reason I came was to relieve stress due to family health situations and the circle definitely met my needs. Alan did a great job leading the circle with the drumming and the short history lessons about drumming and Africa. I will be coming back.

Paul 10/13

This Drum Circle is a great stress reliever after a long week of work and I wish it were every Friday night!! Boston Drum Cirlce attracts a wonderful , eclectic group of people that share the common bond of hand drumming. It is always wonderful to have the multi talented Fanta leading the Circle. Alan and Fanta

Please join the Red Sox Natives hosted by Bob at Laurie's and others for the return of The North Avenue Band as they perform at Laurie's 9:09 on Friday,  November 6 after 7:00pm. The performance features all Classic Rock songs. For more info on the band go to http://www.northavenuebandwakefield.com.

We will be gathering near both the Penny Lane and Nickel Bars at Laurie's.

There is no cover.

The live performance will begin at approximately 7:09pm.

Stay for appetizers, dinner, a cocktail or two or three, socializing and more. If you have a group of people that want a table reservation for dinner please call Laurie's at[masked] and make a reservation. For information on Laurie's 909 and the menu go to www.lauries909.com.

Get there when you can and stay as long as you are able. You are more than welcome to show up for all or just part of the event.

If this will be your first time meeting the Red Sox Natives Crew check out the photos of those who RSVP Yes so you can find the group.

Please remember to maintain your own tab or pay as you order and tip your servers. However, if you sit at a group table a group bill may be provided so please communicate with your server when ordering. Credit Cards will be held by the servers at Laurie's.

Laurie's 909 is one of Wakefield's newest restaurant and Bar with live entertainment several nights per week along with many special E Mail promotions. Laurie's is located at the Wakefield Commuter Rail Train Station in Wakefield. The Reading and Haverhill Commuter Rail trains stop at Laurie's. Laurie's is easily accessible within 10 minutes from Routes 128, 93, 28 and 1. Free parking is available in two lots on Tuttle Street, in the Church parking lot if there are no activities there, and on street after 5:00pm. Check out the MBTA or Hop Stop for additional public transit options including the less reliable/frequent 136 and 137 bus lines.

See you there!

results.description:
Our theme this time will be "Creating New Futures"! You'll leave feeling filled with good feelings about your life, from your past and all the way forward, as we take a trip through your timeline filled with love, wisdom, and whatever else you want to "pack".  Join us for three glorious, insightful, creative meditations!

Take some time to slow down, deeply relax, tune in, and connect deeply to yourself and others. 

Note: For now, we'll be meeting on the first and third Friday evening each month. Of course, you do not have to commit to attending every time, however, the more you attend, the more you will benefit; and the better we'll get to know each other!  Feel free to invite friends and family, too!

See end of description below for  different payment options.

Here's the basic description, with a more specific focus/theme each time, as well:


Take the time to slow down, tune in, and connect deeply with yourself and others.


Are you aware of the many benefits of meditating, but can’t get yourself to do it, or it’s too difficult to do on your own?

Do you enjoy the collective energy and ease of guided group meditations?

Meditation can be one of the easiest and most effective means to living with greater harmony, happiness and well-being. It’s also an opportunity to peacefully transform your problems, your fears, and any pain and stress in your life into something more positive.

I also consider meditating one of the most direct and easiest ways to connect to your greater Spirit-Self, and to access all that it has to offer you.


By participating in these group guided meditations, you’ll experience how simple,delightful and easy it can be. You’ll learn and practice:

• Simple yet profound techniques you can easily do for yourself for any length of time that is comfortable for you.

• How to easily get into a meditative state to deeply relax and to create positive, pleasurable feelings, including inner peace, love, ease and joy; and how to bring that into your daily living.

• Techniques to help you shift your perspective and experience of issues in your life causing you stress in some form, and to shift to a more positive perspective, instead.

• How to connect to your inner resources and your best self, to solution consciousness, and how to activate your body's natural healing response.

We have a different theme each time we meet to help build and reinforce positive thinking patterns, beliefs and inner narratives that will support you in living with greater inner peace, love, ease and joy.

We typically have 2-3 guided meditations, with discussion and instruction in between to help you carry the positive feelings and lessons experienced into your day and life.

This is a perfect time to let go of stress and "busy-ness", and to fully let go and relax into bliss. Come with whatever intentions suit you, and the evening is still sure to satisfy. It always works out magically that way.

You're encouraged to bring a journal or notebook and pen to class.

To encourage and support your practice, if you pay for 4 sessions, the fee will be only $60 (in-person, cash or check), to be used within 4 months of your payment.  Or, you can pay for one class at a time for $20.  Just RSVP each time you want to attend. RSVP is recommended and appreciated, as well as showing up or changing your RSVP in a timely manner.

“I'm leaving refreshed, optimistic, empowered, full of love, and excited about bringing more spirit into everything I do. I’m sure that practicing the techniques I learned tonight will help me very much. Thank you!!! "

"Great meditations! I had a marvelous experience with each of them and a lot to take with me: powerful imagery, good feelings, and new techniques for connecting myself with the Universe. Loved the “love ripple”!”

"I truly value our time together. I tried two other guided meditation classes with other instructors, and I enjoy your classes the most. Why? Because you give us time to reflect, journal and share. It really helps to deepen my experience and expand my perspective. And honestly, I relate more to your meditations and love the sound of your voice. Your guided meditations are like group therapy for the soul."


Class leader (and meetup organizer): Ann Ide, M.A., has been leading guided meditation classes for years, and is also a certified master practitioner in Neuro-linguistic Programming and Hypnotherapy, and certified NLP Life Coach. Ann coaches people to move beyond their personal struggles, to new levels of harmony, happiness and success. With her expert questioning, inner exploration processes and personal change interventions, clients become able to more easily create the happiness they desire.
results.how_to_find_us: We'll be downstairs in the basement level Roots Studio, enter thru back parking lot, or if go in front door - walk down hallway and stairs will be on the left
results.name: Guided Meditations for Experiencing Greater Inner Peace, Love, Ease and JOY

results.description:
Shamans Susan Angelo and Kelle Sparta offer an evening of Sound Healing and Energetic Healing.


Come and sink into the rich sounds of the drums, rattles, and voices that will bring peace and balance to your heart and body.


 The energy from the September 27 Blood Moon Lunar Eclipse brought us more into ourselves, and now those changes need to be integrated. All changes bring stress even if it they are good changes. So come and relieve the stress and allow yourself to integrate all you have learned from this energy shift.


We are also experiencing high levels of solar flares which are impacting those who are energetically aware at a record rate. 


Come and receive a balancing of your energy field to help lessen the effects of the solar flares and get you ready for the rush of the upcoming holiday season. Give yourself the gift of rest, relaxation, integration, and peace. 


Cost: $20


Sue Angelo created Shamanic Spirit Song blending her natural intuitive gifts with her training as a Shamanic and Energy Practitioner over the past decade. She is certified in the Rhys Thomas Institute of Energy Medicine and also a certified Reiki Master. Having worked professionally in women’s health care for 30 years, she has brought alternative medicine to patients every day. Sue holds a loving, supportive environment while she guides clients to balance their sense of self so they can make positive life changes.


Kelle Sparta is a Transformational Shaman with 25 years of experience in transformational workshops. She has been on the ritual team at Spiral Festival (sister event to LumensGate) and has run many events for local area groups in the last 16 years. Her strengths are in creating safe space, identifying blocks, and providing tools to move through them. She is a psychic, a channel, a medium, a Reiki Master, and an initiator of the highest order.
results.name: Channeled Healing for Stress Relief and Integration

results.description: Sacred breath work and meditation Workshop Date: 11/6/15 Time: 7-8 p.m. Cost: $25 per person Description: Meditation can help us move through many difficult symptoms and feelings, such as stress, anxiety and sleeplessness. If you are experiencing any of these symptoms, meditation combined with breathing techniques, key phrases (or mantra) can help you work through these. These tools will help to eliminate symptoms altogether or at least help them to occur less frequently. Meditation also helps to facilitate healing within the body and through meditation, we allow our minds to be quieted, our bodies to be calm and relaxed. In our busy day-to-day living, finding moments like this are rare. Please join me for a one hour guided meditation and sacred breathwork class to learn some easy techniques that you can apply at home, in the office - or anywhere where you can find a quiet moment. (Please bring your own yoga mat and towels).
results.name: Sacred Breathwork and Meditation workshop at Tai Chi Wellness

results.description:
Friday nights are generally for more experienced students, as we work through some different parts of Fiore's works in a more open format.  New students should take our beginners' class first, or contact our instructors for more information.  We're happy to have visiting scholars from other programs come and play!

We practice L'Arte D'Armizare (The Art of Bearing Arms), a historical European martial art. Our main sources of interpretation are the books (c[masked]) of Fiore dei Liberi, a fencing master from Friuli (thus the non-standard Italian spellings!).

Our students work on a combination of longsword, abrazzare (grappling), daga (dagger/knife) and other weapon skills. These skills are drawn from direct translation from historical sources, developed through multiple physical interpretations and tested at speed. Though we emphasize historical technique, our training sessions are a blend of warmup, interpretation, drill, and for men and women who've passed our safety standards, both focused and open sparring.

Dancers of all ages and abilities are invited to dance barefoot, any way you like, with or without a partner, in a smoke and alcohol free environment. Children are welcome.

 [masked] classAfrican Nia—Alice Heller

Alice Heller blends African dance with Nia technique to provide  a delicious blend of earthy African dance moves with the other dance arts, martial arts and healing arts like yoga. This all level workshop is set to great music that will inspire your somatic experience. www.alicehellerdance.com

After African Nia  enjoy dancing to music by DJ David Hero

Dance Friday is an activity of the non-profit Movement Collective. Suggested Donation: $15 8pm-9:15, $10-15 after 9:30, $5-10 after 11,  under  23 years old $5-15, or donate 45 minutes of your time to help out.  We recommend casual, light-weight, comfortable clothing that you can  move in.

results.description:
Welcome future dance-a-holics!! Come dance with us again THIS FRIDAY! If you want to learn to social dance and have a blast while doing it, please join me for a beginner west coast swing class from 8:30-9:15pm (Experienced with WCS? Join Marcus Schwarz for the Intermediate class at 8:30!). If you like it and feel like sticking around, there is a west coast social dance from 9:15-11pm.

You don't need a partner.

You don't need to have any previous dance experience.

You can have two left feet.

This is all about having a blast while learning something new that you can actually use in your real life!

WHAT IS WEST COAST SWING?

West Coast Swing (WCS) is a modern, partnered social dance done all over the world.

It is danced to a wide variety of music, including R&B, Rock, Blues, and Lyrical: exactly what’s on the radio today and at functions you attend!

It fits in small spaces like bars, crowded dance floors—even your living room.

You do not need a partner to get started.  Most people come by themselves or with friends.

Once you’re hooked, there are places to dance WCS every night of the week in the Boston area.

People of all ages dance WCS.
results.name: Beginner & Intermediate West Coast Swing Class & Social Dance!

results.description:
Hey y'all,

We are bringing SILENT SERVANT to town and we can't wait. This one is going to be a little darker than usual but just as fun.

Silent Servant’s prolific output as a producer and artist has laid the groundwork for much of the most ambitious and forward thinking electronic music of today. As a member of the now defunct Sandwell District, he helped force the hand of change with uncompromising ability. And still, he continues to do so with even greater strength and success.

No time has been wasted in the wake of Sandwell District’s 2011 demise. Along with Regis and James Ruskin, Silent Servant founded the Jealous God label. In it’s short existence, they have already cut-up and reinterpreted many of the conventions of the techno world, forging a unique identity in the process. With it’s highly conceptual aesthetic and relentless dedication to experiment, Jealous God is a flag-bearer for the contemporary electronic avant-garde and a loyal ally to all mutant experimentalists. Along with Jealous God, Silent Servant produces and curates for the Downwards imprint, which, throughout it’s 20 year history, has continued to remain at the forefront of the underground techno world. Inherently obscure, their operation is indirect, and easily they deceive introspection. Consciously working as outsiders and avoiding club lavishness, they earn their respect with less mercy than the hyena his food. While insincerity remains the safety of many, Silent Servant’s own productions are brutally honest and resolute, rendering irrelevant those mongering for light. Deeply pensive and forward thinking, his sound is marked by a distinct blend of the disparate and divergent. An appreciation of warehouse techno, industrial noise and post-punk are evident, yet challenged and reworked to form a uniquely modern style - a vitality so controlled and concentrated that it captivates immediately. His live sets are another matter of inventiveness. The superfluous eliminated, Silent Servant has, for years, been rewiring the minds and moving the bodies of those seeking the most meaningful and potent energies that electronic music has to offer.

The future suggests no fatigue or surrender. Having developed a special kind of discipline, Silent Servant will no doubt continue to drive forward, bringing the truly adventurous with him. His criterion of action is freedom of movement, timelessness of expression, freedom for transgression; holding truth at most high. To that end, there is no compromise.


:: DJs ::

SILENT SERVANT

MATT MCNEILL

CHAD SPIGNER


19+ $15
Party by CSC
Visuals by Jon Von Bonk
Artwork by Dan Dabu
results.name: CSC presents SILENT SERVANT w/ Matt McNeill and Chad Spigner

results.description:
Over a year ago, men from many men's circles gathered together.  While respecting each circle's uniqueness, we celebrated our similarities, gathering simply as men -- without tribal separations.  We walked away understanding that we are all "one big team". 

It is time again to gather the men of Greater Boston together in the spirit of brotherhood. 

We will reflect on the dawn -- of the day and of the rest of our lives. We will share, in the still, quiet moment of the rising morning sun, the freedom of nothing to do and nowhere to go but to commune with powerful men supporting one another.

Castle Island at Sunrise:

Greater Boston has several vibrant men’s communities -- the Mankind Project, Men’s Division International, Bushido, the Surround, etc.  Whether you are already part of such a community, whether you are looking to join such a community, or whether you are simply intrigued about finding meaning in a morning spent amongst a band of brothers, we encourage you to join us.  

All men are welcome!  There will be several men who will be participating for the first time, so don't think twice about coming on your own.   You will be welcomed.

We hope you will join us. 


We gather at 5AM in the parking lot:
https://www.google.com/maps?f=q&hl=en&q=42.338642,-71.014170

The Men of Thunder
<a>[masked]</a>

results.description:
The Jaycee walking club!
I am extending you this invite to get you moving!
We meet Saturday mornings, 7:45 am, Fruit Street Mansfield, WW II Veterans Memorial Trail (Bike Path). Just past the airport. We go for just about a 4 mile walk, takes a little over an hour, and we have lots of fun. If you can’t do the 4 miles come and do what you can and work your way up. We usually have enough people to split up into sub-groups of leisure walkers and speedsters.

I use Map My Walk to keep track of our time and distance. This is a free app that you can download to your smartphone, should you want to start keeping track of your exercise, minutes and calories burned. It has a lot of features that I am sure you would have fun with.

If you can, let me know if you will be walking with us, so we don’t start without you. If we are all gathered before 8 we tend to just get going at that point.

If you are interested in joining our walking club, either this time or sometime in the future, please let me know and I will include you on that email list.

results.description:
Event Organizer: Michael Blair @ (978)[masked]


=====

Read the entire description before you RSVP and answer all of the questions that are part of the process. Failure to answer them will result in your removal from this event.

Answers DO NOT carry over from one event to another so you must answer them for EACH EVENT. Also, questions might not show up if you RSVP from a phone or tablet so if you don't see them you will need to use a computer.

If you underestimate the demands of this event; overestimate your experience, knowledge, skills or abilities; or come unprepared you put yourself and others at risk. Consider this before you RSVP.

=== What We're Doing ===

The plan is to hike to two of the 4,000 footers in New Hampshire - Flume and Liberty. We will use Lincoln Woods Trail and Osseo Trail to reach Flume. From there we will use Franconia Ridge Trail to reach Liberty and then use Liberty Spring Trail and Whitehouse Trail to get to the trailhead.

If you are interested in participating in this event sign up for the waiting list. I will add people that (1) answer all of the questions that are part of the RSVP process and (2) have done similar hikes within the past three months.

The maximum group size for this trip will be 12 people. 

Guests aren't permitted.

Dogs are only permitted with prior approval of the event organizer.

=== Trip Summary ===

We start as a group, hike as a group, and finish as a group. Our pace will be that of the slowest hiker. This trip isn't for you if you are faster than the group and don't want to stay with us, if you want to head off on your own, or if you are slower than the group and expect us to constantly wait for you.

On this moderate pace (~2.0 MPH) trip we will hike about 10.6 miles and climb about 4,000 feet. It should take an average hiker about 7 hours 30 minutes to complete. This event is considered INTERMEDIATE because of the pace, distance, and elevation gain.

Use this link for more information about where we are going and how we will get there:

http://trailsnh.com/peaks/nh/4000/18-Mt-Liberty-4459--25-Mt-Flume-4328


Dangerous weather conditions will cancel this event - I will post an update and/or send an email to all confirmed participants. Use this link for the current weather forecast:

http://forecast.weather.gov/MapClick.php?lon=-71.64193255004888&lat=44.115640688381006#.Vi2GgYTO5_Y


=== What to Bring ===


IT'S WINTER IN THE MOUNTAINS - WINTER CLOTHING AND GEAR IS REQUIRED FOR THIS HIKE. DON'T THINK WE WILL NEED SNOWSHOES BUT WINTER BOOTS, TRACTION (E.G. KAHTOOLA MICROSPIKES OR HILLSOUND TRAIL CRAMPONS), AND WEATHER APPROPRIATE CLOTHING IS REQUIRED. EXPERIENCE IN WINTER IS ALSO REQUIRED.

Use this link for a list of items needed for a winter day hike:


</a><a href="http://files.meetup.com/492954/Winter_Day_Hike_List_ADK.pdf">http://files.meetup.com/492954/Winter_Day_Hike_List_ADK.pdf

Do not rely on others to have extra items to share with you at the meeting spot or on the trail. You should know how to use all of your equipment - test and adjust it prior to this trip. 

=== Directions ===

We will meet at the Whitehouse Trailhead which is in the parking lot about 1/4 mile north of the Flume Visitor Center on Route 3 near Lincoln, NH. According to Google Maps this spot is about 134 miles from Boston and it will take about 2 hours 4 minutes to drive there. Since that is where we will end our trip we will leave a few cars there and drive to the start.

Use this link to customize the driving directions:

https://goo.gl/maps/ghWWXY4US8U2


While carpooling is encouraged you are responsible for coordinating your own rides. Use the comments section below to communicate with others who may also be looking to share a ride.

=== Random Group of Hikers Disclaimer ===

As a condition of your voluntary participation in this activity you acknowledge and agree to the following: this activity involves inherent risks that can cause property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death to participants and/or others; you assume all risk associated with this activity; you are responsible for having the necessary knowledge, skills, abilities, clothing, and equipment to safely participate in this activity; you know and will follow the Hike Safe Responsibility Code; the organizer(s) of this activity are volunteers; and you release, hold harmless, and indemnify the organizer(s) and all members of this group from any and all claims for property damage, injury, illness, disability, and/or death - including those caused by negligence and/or other reasons.

results.description:
• [Don't be concerned if you don't see many RSVPs here... our members tend to RSVP via our members site at WatertownSaturdayToastmasters.org.]

Please arrive at 9:00 am. From 9 to 9:15 am, we set up the meeting and network. We start the meeting at 9:15 am, and continue until 10:45 am. When you enter Church of the Good Shepherd, walk downstairs and take a left. If you arrive late, just walk in and have a seat at any open spot.

Please visit "Meeting Roles & Responsibilities" for more information about what to expect from a club meeting.

Here's a sample agenda for our meeting:

9:00 AM Setting up/Networking

9:15 AM President's Greeting and Club announcements

Welcome all to the First Watertown Saturday club.

Toastmaster's Welcome 

Introduces each role, its purpose, and the person who will perform the role.

Humorist/Invocation

Starts the meeting on a light-hearted note.

Grammarian's Word of the Day

Encourages each of us to add a new word to our vocabularies. Challenge us to use the new word spontaneously.

Scheduled Speeches


Club members give the speeches that they've scheduled and prepared in advance using the guidelines from one of the Toastmasters International communication manuals.

Table Topics

Our meeting's Topicsmaster provides our members and guests with an opportunity for demonstrating and honing their skills for impromptu speaking.

General Evaluator's Introduction


Introduces evaluation team members and evaluate the evaluators and the meeting in general.

Speech Evaluations


Club members provide helpful, supportive feedback to each of the scheduled speaker in a positive and friendly manner.

Grammarian's Report

Grammarian reports on how many times speakers used the Word of the Day and how we used the English language.

Ah-Counter's Report

Ah-counter reports how many filler-words and false starts were used by each participant, to raise speakers' awareness of these instances and to encourage improvement.

Timer's Report

Timer reports speaking times of all major speaking roles to encourage members learn to accomplish tasks within set time limits.

General Evaluator's Report

General evaluator provides a review of the meeting, what went well, and areas for improvement to encourage continual growth and an optimal quality of our meetings.

Toastmaster's Closing Remarks 

10:45 AM President Adjourns Meeting

We usually have a convivial lunch at The Red Lentil. Hang around after the meeting for details.

WatertownSaturdayToastmasters.org

results.description:
Join us for a relaxed ride along the coast north of Boston, stopping at major beaches and exploring new ones.


No one left behind, average riding speed would be around 12 miles/hr (faster if all of us can keep up).

We would go all the way to Salem and catch the 5:50 PM train back to North Station. If we reach before 3, anyone who wishes can take the 3:20 PM train.

Boston to Salem is just 18 miles if we go straight, but we would be visiting many beaches along the way, so our ride won't be a straight line. 

Route plan is

• Start from Maverick Station main entrance

• Enter East Boston Greenway


• Visit Constitution Beach


• Take right on Orient Heights station and head to Deer Island Park (enjoy the coastal ride)

• Head to Revere Beach


• Visit Nahant Beach - then visit Canoe Beach in Nahant

• Ride to Marblehead, visit Devereux Beach

• If we all agree, then goto Chandler Hoovey Park at the end of peninsula

• Head to Salem


• Have "unpretentious coffee" at Gulu-Gulu Café


• Take the train back to North Station

Heading Back

It would take around 3.5 hours and including stops it might take as much as 4.5 hours. We would reach Salem by 2:30 PM and have enough time to enjoy downtown and have lunch together.

Car Parking options

* Park at Government Center Garage and take the Outbound Blue Line fromAquarium Station to Maverick Station

* Park-And-Ride at Wonderland. $5 for first 14 hours. Take the Inbound Blue Line from Wonderland Station to Maverick Station

* Park-And-Ride at Orient Heights. $5 for 24 hours. Take the Inbound Blue Line from Orient Heights to Maverick station

* Boston Common Garage. $18 on weekend. Take the Outbound Blue Line from Bowdoin/State Street Station to Maverick
results.how_to_find_us: I would be standing just outside the main entrance of Maverick station (from where you can catch the bus)
results.name: Beach Hopping - Boston to Salem  (35-40 miles) via North Shore Islands (One Way)

results.description:
Making tea is easy with leaves and flowers, but what about those plants whose active properties are located in the roots? If you've ever wondered what you could do with the echinacea, burdock or dandelions in your garden, this class is for you! Remedies from the roots of various herbs are best prepared in the fall after first frost. We'll walk through the process of digging, cleaning, and preparing several root herbs and along the way discuss handy rules of thumb for working with any herb. results.description:
We practice L'Arte D'Armizare (The Art of Bearing Arms), a historical European martial art. Our main sources of interpretation are the books (circa[masked]) of Fiore dei Liberi, a fencing master from Friuli (thus the non-standard Italian spellings!).

Our students work on a combination of longsword, abrazzare (grappling), daga (dagger/knife) and other weapon skills. These skills are drawn from direct translation from historical sources, developed through multiple physical interpretations and tested at speed. Though we emphasize historical technique, our training sessions are a blend of warmup, interpretation, drill, and for men and women who've passed our safety standards, both focused and open sparring.

New students should take our beginners' class first, or contact our instructors for more information.  We're happy to have visiting scholars from other programs come and play!

See you there!

If there's no parking in Thorndike lot, look for parking on the side streets.

results.description:
(a set of 4 Saturday classes)


Always wanted to learn how they really fought in the middle ages? Forget any ideas about crude battering on armour; the successful warrior strikes to the gaps and the openings of his or her opponent's attacks, and supplements this with disarms, throws, and other techniques which secure the advantage over larger or stronger attackers.

Around the year 1400, Fiore dei Liberi trained medieval knights and squires, and authored multiple books of medieval combat, some of which have survived to the present day. His method, L'Arte d'Armizare (the Art of Bearing Arms), shows an integrated and cross-referenced system of sword, dagger, grappling, spear & lance, pollaxe and other weapons on foot and on horseback, with and without armour, and easily dispels any illusions that medieval combat was about unskilled strength.

Our beginners' course is four linked classes that give the basic techniques and vocabulary of L'Arte, and enables men and women to begin regular unarmoured training and learning.  No prior training needed; all class equipment is provided.

So, come join the scholars and combatants of our company!

(The price shown is for the set of all four classes (Oct 24, 31, Nov. 7 and 14) and membership and registration.  Classes are not offered separately.  We'll send an email with some class materials before the first session.)

results.description:
This look like an interesting and unique place to try for lunch this fall.  The link to the menu is below along with a summary of their food. Excellent reviews on Yelp.

http://www.fusionandinarestaurant.com/menu/soups/

Fusion Andina is a restaurant where you can find the richness of the Andean Food, specifically from Bolivia and Peru.  Our Bolivian and Peruvian cuisine stems mainly from the combination of Spanish Cuisine with traditional Indigenous Aymara ingredients. The three traditional staples of Bolivian cuisine are corn, potatoes and beans. These ingredients have been combined with a number of staples brought by the Spanish, such as rice and wheat and meats such as beef, pork, and chicken.

In our recipes, we want to promote the Quinoa which is an organic grain crop grown primarily for its edible seeds. It is a pseudo cereal rather than a true cereal, as it is not a member of the true grass family. As a chenopod, quinoa is closely related to species such as beetroots, spinach and tumbleweeds.

***CAVEAT: This event offers some VERY INTERESTING speakers, but BVM does not endorse any of the speakers, tablers-exhibitors, messages, sponsors, or direct or indirect influences on the production of this event!

We believe that the issues and problems and probably the data will be factual and useful for policy-oriented persons.  Be prepared to present great questions, if you go!***

The Union of Concerned Scientists invites you to join the conversation on the many facets of food at the 4th annual Let's Talk about Food Festival in Boston's beautiful Copley Square.

SOME of this you will LOVE.

But there will be some points you will DETEST.

We WELCOME your HECKLING and HOLDING UP 
and WAVING PROTEST SIGNS is WELCOMED (when appropriate).

Thousands of area residents, chefs, public health professionals, and scientists will come together for demonstrations and lively discussions on healthy food access, nutrition, added sugar labeling, community-scientist partnerships, corporate influence on food policy, sustainable agriculture, and much more.

Let's Talk About Food Festival

Date: Saturday, October 3

Time: 10:00 a.m. - 5:00 p.m. EDT

Location: Copley Square, Boston

Ricardo Salvador, director of the UCS Food & Environment Program, and other special guests willspeak at noon for approximately 45 minutes. Immediately following, Ricardo, staff from the Center for Science and Democracy, and other local experts will lead the Endless Table discussions for the next hour.

Additional guests include:

• Dr. Marion Nestle, professor of nutrition, food studies, and public health, New York University, and member, UCS National Advisory Board;

• Roger Berkowitz, president & CEO, Legal Sea Foods;

• P.K. Newby, nutrition scientist;

• And

more

Check out the program of events, and come join the conversation!

results.description:
here are the resting places of the Pilgrims? Discover how many of the settlers who arrived on the first four ships to Plymouth (Mayflower, Fortune, Anne, Little James), may be interred on Burial Hill. Stephen O’Neill, curator of Pilgrim Hall Museum, examines the evidence for their burials, including later gravestones on the Hill, death records, and even the burial practices and beliefs of the Pilgrims themselves.


Tours begin at the top of the Hill; no reservations are required.

Participants may traverse steep and slippery slopes; please wear appropriate shoes.


Severe weather may cancel tour; updates will be posted on the Plymouth Antiquarian Society Facebook page.

FREE

results.description:
This session is designed for students who have already taken an intro to Python, Java, C/C++, or Javascript course (programming beyond HTML/CSS or Scratch). Exceptions may be granted with instructor permission. Students should be familiar with variables, if statements, and loops.

Please arrive prepared with a laptop that already has Python installed and running: https://www.python.org/downloads/. Please also install the IPython (http://ipython.org/install.html), Natural Language Processing Toolkit (http://www.nltk.org/install.html), the full SciPy stack (http://scipy.org/install.html), and SciKit Learn (http://scikit-learn.org/stable/install.html). If you have trouble with this, please still come to the session, but we have a STRONG preference for having this taken care of at home so that we can focus on learning new things.

Depending on student interest and ability, we may cover Cryptography and Computer Security, Spam (Junk Email) Detection, Data Visualization, and an introduction to Machine Learning. If possible, please email [masked] a brief summary of your student's programming experience and interests. Feel free to also email any questions or concerns. Accommodations and modifications will be made to fit student interest and ability.

Students are encouraged to explore the online documentation themselves and experiment with running their own code before class.

This will be the first of a 5-session course, where students will be expected to remember what we learned the previous week. The first session is on 11/7, and the following dates are 11/14, 11/21, 12/5, and 12/12.
results.name: Advanced Programming

Note: 

There will be no face to face meetup unless we reach 50 RSVPs by Thursday of the week. You must be enrolled in one of the 10 FREE courses below or similar courses. 

Our past experience is that 20% of the RSVP shows up in the weekend meetings. Considering that, unless we have about 50 RSVPs, we cannot have a face to face meeting. Please use the questions / answers / discussions below for now. While asking questions, please make reference to the name of the course and the related module within the course. 

Cousera offers the following classes towards obtaining highly valuable knowledge/skills in Data Science Specialization. It is sometimes hard to work on the exercises and homework without the help of an expert.  Receiving one-on-one help from an expert can improve the commitment of finishing the program with accelerated learning. With that in mind, we are experimenting with the following service.


An expert (MS or PhD in Statistics) will answer any question free that takes less than 10 minutes to solve. There are nominal fees for one-on-one interactive help.  Please use the following link to request for help, or just email [masked] or call[masked]-8864.

http://www.tutorteddy.com/courses/coursera-course-help.php

The Data Scientist’s Toolbox

R Programming

Getting and Cleaning Data

Exploratory Data Analysis

Reproducible Research

Statistical Inference

Regression Models

Practical Machine Learning

Developing Data Products

Data Science Capstone

Anybody up for a Scavenger Hunt? Feel free to invite friends!

Watson Adventures
Bos - The Murder at the Science Museum Scavenger Hunt
$33.50 per person. For tickets: https://web.ovationtix.com/trs/pe.c/10024539
For Adults Only
Saturday, November 7, 2015 at 2:00PM

at The Museum of Science
Science Park
Boston, MA 02114
US

All tickets include admission to the museum. (Please note that Watson Adventures is required to pay admission for each person who participates in the event. There are no special ticket types or discounts for members.)

Hunts are played on teams of two to six players. Someone, or something, has been bumping off museum staffers involved in the recent discovery of a long-lost invention by Benjamin Franklin. This “infernal machine” has a murky past: Freemasons supposedly used it as part of a secret ritual. Are the deaths caused by the invention, or part of the fabled “Curse of the Freemasons”? Or is a serial killer on the loose? Your team of sleuths will have to crack a secret code and uncover the museum’s secrets to solve the mystery and stop the killings. This hunt is for adults only. Teams consist of two to six people. For murder hunts, we strongly recommend hunting with a team of three or more. If you sign up with fewer than three people, we suggest pairing up with others at the start of the hunt to form a larger team

Watson Adventures
Bos - The Murder at the Science Museum Scavenger Hunt
$33.50 per person. For tickets: https://web.ovationtix.com/trs/pe.c/10024539
For Adults Only
Saturday, November 7, 2015 at 2:00PM

at The Museum of Science
Science Park
Boston, MA 02114
US

All tickets include admission to the museum. (Please note that Watson Adventures is required to pay admission for each person who participates in the event. There are no special ticket types or discounts for members.)

Hunts are played on teams of two to six players. Someone, or something, has been bumping off museum staffers involved in the recent discovery of a long-lost invention by Benjamin Franklin. This “infernal machine” has a murky past: Freemasons supposedly used it as part of a secret ritual. Are the deaths caused by the invention, or part of the fabled “Curse of the Freemasons”? Or is a serial killer on the loose? Your team of sleuths will have to crack a secret code and uncover the museum’s secrets to solve the mystery and stop the killings. This hunt is for adults only. Teams consist of two to six people. For murder hunts, we strongly recommend hunting with a team of three or more. If you sign up with fewer than three people, we suggest pairing up with others at the start of the hunt to form a larger team
results.name: Scavenger Hunt in Boston

results.description:
Join University of Massachusetts Cranberry expert Carolyn DeMoranville for a fun day learning all about cranberries in Massachusetts. 

The history of cranberry as a food crop in Massachusetts from pre-European times will be reviewed. Current conditions, including environmental sustainability challenges and innovations will be presented. The program will conclude with information on expanding uses for the fruit.

Carolyn DeMoranville is and Extension Associate Professor and Director of the UMass Amherst Cranberry Station. She has a Ph.D. in Plant and Soil Sciences and conducts research on plant nutrient management and horticultural management practices for cranberry. A Massachusetts native, for Carolyn, cranberries are the family business. Her grandfather built cranberry bogs in the 1950s and her father was a cranberry researcher and extension specialist with a cranberry cultivar named for him!

Pre-registration will be required for this event, once we get closer to the event date. Please check back here soon for details on when registration will be available.


http://www.thetrustees.org/things-to-do/greater-boston/bpm-1101.html?srregion=&srrelated_property=&srevent_type=lectures-workshops&dateType=srevent_start_date&srstartDate=&srendDate=&x=35&y=15
results.name: Cranberries - History, Sustainability and New Uses

results.description:
In and Out of Sync: How Does Light Impact Our Health?
Date: This Saturday, November 7, 2015, 2:00pm
Location: Harvard Science Center Hall C, 1 Oxford Street, Harvard Square, Cambridge, MA 02138

In and Out of Sync: How Does Light Impact Our Health?Date: Saturday, November 7, 2015, 2:00pmSee also: 


Public Lectures

Lectures

http://static.hwpi.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_large/public/hmnh/files/roguliga.banner_0.jpg?m=1445954701&itok=-3xNDzNX * Dragana Rogulja, Assistant Professor in Neurobiology, Harvard Medical School
* Holly W. Samuelson, Assistant Professor of Architecture, Harvard Graduate School of Design

Natural light stimulates people's circadian clocks, keeping activities synchronized with the day-night cycle.
How can building design satisfy occupants' biological and psychological need for natural light, while also balancing issues of glare, thermal comfort, and energy savings?

Dragana Rogulja and Holly Samuelson will discuss the importance of light in both daily life and built environments, as well as its impact on overall well-being.

Part of the What's Light Got to Do With It? Lecture Series, presented in partnership with the Harvard Brain Science Initiative and the Harvard Art Museums.

Free parking is available at the 52 Oxford Street Garage.
Free and open to the public.
results.name: In and Out of Sync: How Does Light Impact Health?

results.description:
Once again, just kidding, I know you're not effing around! But what's going on? What are you producing? As an actor, a filmmaker?

This meeting will be focused on identifying resources and taking action with regard to production. Tell us what your plan is and when you're gonna do it. And then report back. Maybe someone here can help you. Even if it's just something super short...even just 10 to 30 seconds...!! Create something for your reel.

 That said, as always, and depending on how many people attend, we will divide up the time equally for people to use (if wanted) - to explore an idea, a scene, an improv... anything that is relevant to your process. Each person is responsible for directing the use of their own allotted time.

With regard to production: Poiesis Studio has just joined Somerville Community Access Television as a group member. Which means all members of Poiesis Studio, whether you live in Somerville or not, are eligible to become SCATV members -- which confers many benefits: very inexpensive production classes, the opportunity to be trained and gain free access to an incredible array of resources including - camera's, lighting, sound equipment, full production studio, etc.. 

In the near future we will schedule some meetings at the SCATV Studio. If you're not familiar with it, it's a great place with very cool people!!

with regard to RSVP:

please don't just show up to check out the meeting without RSVP-ing.

If you RSVP yes, but need to cancel, please do so ASAP as space is limited.

I am requesting a $5.00 donation from attendees, or whatever you can give. If that's not possible right now, don't worry, rsvp and come anyway. 

I look forward to seeing you!

-Robert
results.name: How to Stop Effing Around and PRODUCE SOME CONTENT!!

You should feel comfortable swimming at least a couple lengths continuously (but if you're not and would be interested in learning to swim, leave a comment and maybe we can organize something!).

The pool opens at 2pm, so we'll meet to go in around 1:45 so that we can be out on the pool deck by 2. $6 to get in, Cambridge residents $5 (or you can buy a 10-pack for an approximate 10% discount, and we do these weekly so you'll have the opportunity to use them up).

Street parking is available but stressful, and the 69 bus drops off down the block, or you can bike or run there and do 2/3 of a triathlon :)

results.description:
Join us for a walk through Norris Reservation!  Hike past a former mill pond, cross a wetlands boardwalk, and explore a forest of pine and oak on your way to a boathouse on the banks of the tidal North River.

What makes the Norris Reservation a special place?

A herring brook wends along the western edge of the reservation, which also boasts boulders left by the glacier, a riverside boathouse, and several prime picnic spots.  For many walkers, reaching the lovely curve in the North River is ample reward; currents can be especially dynamic at this stretch of the meandering tidal stream. Stop at the boat house or at an overlook bench and wait for wading birds, hawks, and kingfishers – and the occasional boater – to pass by. Within the reservation’s interior is the Gordon’s pond. Look for crumbling beaver dams in the wetlands or listen for an owl’s hoot.


Admission:
Members: FREE. Nonmembers: $5 parking fee. Get more information about parking fees >>

Directions: From Rt. 3, take Exit 13 onto Rt. 53 North. Follow for 0.6 mi. Turn right onto Rt. 123 (Main St.) and follow for 3 mi. towards Norwell center. Just before entering town center, turn right onto West St. and  follow for 0.3 mi. until it dead ends into Dover St. Entrance and parking area  (12 cars) are straight ahead on Dover St.
results.how_to_find_us: Let's meet at the trail's entrance by the big sign.
results.name: Walk at Norris Reservation, Norwell

group.name: Health Nuts of the South Shore Meetup

results.description:
MIT in Cambridge has some very unique buildings and sculptures and I'd like to take a small tour to catch a few of the best. Topic is advanced architecture and I encourage you to either attempt long exposures during the day (which needs a strong neutral density filter, 10 or 16 stops) or HDR processing to deal with the bright daytime skies. This meetup will also extend into twilight and darkness.


See the map below for a possible route to walk, but we can cut that short as needed. We will meet at the alchemist's numbers head at point A, then go right behind it to take photos of the Kresge auditorium and chapel (B), then mosey on to Simmons Hall (C), a very cool building structure, just to go back the same way along Vassar to the Stata building (point D).


I realize that some people can spend the entire evening at that building complex, but I plan to move on after some time to the Media lab (E), which is cool and the Dept of Engineering building right across (the one with the sharp corner) and finally to the Sloan School of Management (F). If you're still not tired and have to go back to where we met, you can take photos at the Killian Court (the bldg with the dome). And, of course, there are several cool sculptures scattered around the MIT campus. Plus, we're right at the water and there are some interesting boating places across the street.

Here is a link to a previous meetup in that location (all at night) and here is another one for inspiration.


Weather forecast right now is for a partly sunny day, which would give us cool clouds, 60°F.

Suggested equipment:

Camera, tripod, remote/intervalometer to do HDR, long exposures or photography after dark. Lenses: fisheye, wide angle to normal range, tilt-shift if you have one, lens baby, medium-range zoom up to 100 mm may come in handy for shots across the water. Wear some comfortable shoes or hiking boots, it's a bit of walking.


Point A: the alchemist. This is where we meet.

Point B, the Kresge Auditorium, right behind it:

Point C, Simmons Hall

Point D, the famous Stata Building (see link above, this here is the backside, across the street, also interesting)

Point E, Media Lab and Dept of Engineering:

and finally point F, Sloan School.

and here is Killian Court on your way back to Mass Ave:

And the map with a possible walking route:
results.name: MIT Architecture, HDR, long exposures

results.description:
Come join us for an evening of excellent live music and dance performances - one show at 3:00pm and the second at 7:30pm.

Fellswater is one of Boston's most dynamic instrumental Celtic music ensembles. They play a wide range of music from traditional to modern compositions that draw on the heritage of all the Celtic nations, especially Scotland, Ireland, Brittany, and Canada. Since they are a group of virtuosos, their instrumentation changes depending on the musical selection and includes whistle, flute, guitar, bouzouki, violin, and smallpipes. The concert also features Scottish dancing as well as Scottish music. Choreographed country dance medleys weave in and out of the musical segments, performed by the Boston Branch Demonstration Team, often in period costume or full Highland dress. We also feature champion Highland dancers, such as Karen Campbell Mahoney and Highland Dance Boston.

More info and tickets at http://rscdsboston.org/Concert2015/concert2015.html.
results.name: 22nd Annual Concert of Scottish Music and Dance

results.description:
Calling all classical musicians of intermediate level or beyond to get together and play with each other as soloists or in groups. I am a pianist and violinist and want to create a regular venue for other amateur classical instrumentalists to play for and with each other in a fun and encouraging environment (music + talking + drinks). Jamming is also encouraged so feel free to bring chamber music that we could read through together. The music room has a grand piano and 3 music stands.

We've had 3 meetups with pianists, violinist, violists, flautists, clarinetists, and a ukulele player.  The formats are various: piano solos, string duos, piano+clarinet, piano trios (w/ clarinet), and even a string quartet with a cello substitution.  ;-)

NOTE:   Please RSVP and keep it up-to-date so we can all have a sense of what instruments will be present.
results.name: Get together and play for each other (4th time)!

results.description:
Due to scheduling, no story this month! Instead, we'll read a selection from Toni Morrison's book Playing In the Dark: Whiteness and the Literary Imagination. I will post the excerpt on Wednesday 11/4. To download, go to www.cathyjacobowitz.net/race-fiction-writing and click on "Member Page." I'll send the password to everyone who RSVPs (if you don't get it, feel free to message me). 


Please note some changes: (1) Earlier start time! (2) We're taking suggestions for the discussion topic. If you have an idea for a discussion question about race and fiction, please add it in the comments.


As usual, we'll spend some time in conversation, sharing our writing experiences this month and pondering a question. The second half of the meetup will be devoted to workshopping the story at hand. Plus, cookies, ice cream, espresso drinks, you name it.
